story-story continues where overture ended.youre in a cell,you dont know what happened and because you hear someone being slaughtered you escape,through the vent,then you notice that youre in some underground research lab,where something went wrong with infection and now its spread all over the place.
you encounter your enemy right after you escape from cell and when you encounter him you either a) start vomit b)go blind or c)eat your eyes for breakfast-the only enemies in this game are some kind of naked zombies and you relly dont want to think about what will they do to you if they catch you

joking aside-theyre 10 times better then dog zombies from the last game.you cant kill them and theyre design is .........ehm........lets say original (even though you keep asking yourself why dont they have some clothes.i mean where they having a shower when they transformed or what?)

next thing that 10 times better is the setting(setting in overture was mine)-i liked underground lab,it feels more claustrophobic and they are well designed(in my opinion)and also atmosphere is great

gameplay-you solve puzzles,finding objects,finding notes-typical horror adventure stuff.game has great puzzles that makes you think and notes of events that happened are interesting

if i should pick some flaw-it would be the fact that there is something that can be described as comedy relieve.later there is some voice in your head that was probably one of those zombies and when he speaks it ruins atmosphere.

overall its pretty enjoyable game and i recommend it to those who love horror

8/10

25705523.review: This is by far one of the best survival horror games I've ever played. The first Penumbra game was pretty good, the third was mediocre, but this one was definitely the best of the three. The atmosphere is chilling, the soundtrack is excellent, and the story is pretty interesting. I think it's mostly the soundtrack that made me like this game so much. The music that plays when enemies are around and/or are coming after you gives me goosebumps. It's that kind of music that you randomly remember in the middle of the night and become terrified, and it's those kinds of aspects that I look for in a good horror game. The only complaint that I have about this game is that there isn't any way to skip the dialogue that plays throughout the game (from Clarence) and sometimes it gets rather annoying hearing his voice every couple of minutes. For someone who is playing the game for the first time, I can understand why they'd want to hear the dialogue. However, for someone who is playing it again after having beaten it just to experience the atmosphere again, it gets rather old hearing his voice. Nonetheless, this is a fantastic game and is far better than any recent horror games I've played. If you're a horror fan, I highly recommend this game. You won't be disappointed.

25544671.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague is a very fun and story rich game. It acts as a sequel to Penumbra: Overture and it incorporates many elements of the original into the sequel, like dead versions of enemies from the original and the same overall setting; (Although it disappointingly removed weapons).

This game is mostly driven by horror, however in some parts it uses unique puzzles, which in some cases get mixed with horror; which gave an interesting end result. This game (like it's predecessor) used enemies, though the enemies in Penumbra: Overture were far less scary than the enemies in this game, for many reasons. One of which is that the enemies in this game talk to themselves when they are near you. 

In conclusion, I would highly recommend this game, but you should also play the first one first as it helps a bit with the story (A mistake I made).

24713097.review:
Das Spiel ist ein gutes Survival Horror. Im Vergleich zu seinem Vorgänger (Overture) ist es wesentlich besser.

Das ziemlich schlechte Kampfsystem wurde weggelassen und man sich vor den Feinden nur noch verstecken oder wegrennen (so wie bei Outlast) und da sind einige richtig schreckhafte Momente bei mir dabei gewesen. "You are dead" grummelt der und rennt auf mich zu, ich nur noch weg, nach links, nach rechts, Tür, zu, weiter, nächste Tür, durch, puh, in Sicherheit. Das war richtig toll.

Die Physik wure wesentlich verbessert und intensiviert, so mein Eindruck. Viele Gegenstände sind beweglich und müssen eben auch bewegt, angeordnet oder sonstwie manipuliert werden. Beim Aufmachen einer Tür steht man sich zwar immer noch im Weg, aber das ist, weil alles andere so gut funktioniert, nur etwas mühselig.

Die Grafik war bei mir nun auch besser. Nur wenn es dunkel ist, werden die Texturen ziemlich matschig.

Die Rätsel waren teils leicht, teils anspruchsvoll.

Nur eine Episode zum Ende hin fand ich ziemlich daneben, aber sonst war auch die Geschichte relativ stimmig.

Beim Speichern gab es nun auch erkennbare, bewusst wählbare Speicherpunkte und nicht nur die automatischen Speicherungen beim Betreten eines Raumes.

Pro & Contra:

+ Schöne Horror-Elemente
+ Gute Rätsel
+ Interessante Physik

o Die Grafik ist ausreichend gut aber kein Highlight

- Zum Ende hin machte die Geschichte einen (unnötigen, unpassenden) Abstecher

Wertung: 09/10

Das Spiel ist schon ziemlich gute Horror-Adventure-Unterhaltung bei dem der Preis angemessen ist. Kann ich empfehlen.

Bello! Non ci speravo e invece mi è piaciuto anche più del primo Overture.
La storia si sviluppa anche in questo secondo episodio in modo molto intrigante e con gli elementi narrativi distribuiti in modo eccellente. Appagante anche il finale della storia senza tante stravaganze da interpretare ma bello chiaro e deciso!
La qualità grafica è rimasta praticamente quella di Overture ma con qualche miglioramento nelle textures e nelle (poche) animazioni. Anche l'audio è rimasto quello di buon livello del primo episodio.
Interfaccia purtroppo ancora spartana ma per quanto riguarda la giocabilità fortunatamente è stata ben corretta l'eccessiva semplicità degli "incontri" con i vari mostri che minava Overture.
Gli enigmi sono rimasti senza assurdità, molto logici da risolvere ma come per il primo episodio questo potrebbe portare i veterani di avventure a giudicarli (giustamente) troppo facili.
Se avete giocato il primo Penumbra questo Black Plague è assolutamente consigliato per concludere degnamente l'avventura.

23972525.review:
Even though I personally prefer Overture to Black Plague, I have no doubts about recommending this game. Many people consider Black Plague to be the best in the series and it is clear to see why.

Overall Black Plague is a pretty satisfying continuation of the story. It has a longer runtime, more aggressive scare tactics, and better balance.

I am thrilled they did away with all combat and weapons, and the number of enemies was scaled back appropriately. The gameplay flowed much more naturally and felt slightly more polished compared to Overture.

A lot of game-time is spent searching/fetching/backtracking, but I never got lost and my progress was never really halted, so I wouldn't say the game is frustrating in that sense. Not always super fun to run back and forth through the same area repeatedly - there were times when it got old - but for the most part the story helps move everything along. If you can stay immersed, it is fine.

The setting isn't as compelling as the mining tunnels of Overture. Not many memorable environments, a lot of repetition due to the nature of the building. Considering this, I thought they did a great job with exploration and keeping things fresh.

I was missing the role of writings in this game. In Overture there was just enough cryptic information in the form of notes, newspapers, etc. It created a constant duality of discovery and horror. In Black Plague there were almost no interesting notes to find. Instead I felt like information was just being thrown at me from every direction and I was told too much too soon. There was almost no sense of mystery left. 

Have to say I wasn't a fan of the many new characters/people/personalities introduced. There was a lot going on and I never felt isolated. Unfortunately it hurt the tension for me and I ran through the game mostly without fear. Despite that, there is a good amount of horror to this game in the form of some very effective and memorable sequences. Outstanding use of audio and light/dark.

A lot of decent scare tactics are used, along with some cheaper jump-scares, and it's a lot of fun. I enjoyed seeing what they came up with and when the game caught me off guard. It was kind of like a haunted house.

Complaints and nitpicking aside, I had a blast with both games. Penumbra delivered a satisfying experience with plenty of mystery and entertainment. Well done.

23835741.review:
I wanted to like this game, but couldn't. TLDR: It wasn't that much fun overall. Not really much of a horror game (not scary). I found the voice of Clarence to be rather annoying. The puzzles were bothersome at times. The ending took turn way out into left field. 

Longer review:

I will start by saying that although the first installment of this series (Overture) has its flaws, I was able to finish the game without a walkthrough and the story was interesting. Black Plague on the other hand improved upon some of these flaws, but ended up making a worse game in my opinion. 

Story:
Black Plague continues about where Overture left off. However, it goes in an entirely different direction by involving some organization that is apparently a gloabl order. It felt like much of what happened was created after the first game rather than having been the plan for the story all along. By the time I reached the ending, it felt like the story had gone into a whole other direction. And then there is Clarence. He is a voice in your head that (if you play you can figure out how he got there) was just really annoying. I understand the overall contribution of Clarence to the plot, but I would have done it differently myself. But perhaps his annoying voice and dialogue were exactly what the writer(s) wanted to show. Overall, it wasn't satisfying for me.

Gameplay/Puzzles- The gameplay and object interaction were pretty standard if not better than Overture. I definitely think that Black Plague was better off without combat. The enemies were not difficult to face, but rather acted to obstruct you on the way to your next destination. Overall standard gameply. The puzzles were problematic for me as I wasn't really into the game and was in a hurry to finish it, so I often would miss an item that was needed to solve the puzzle. For example, one puzzle required a book or note to tell you how to complete it, but I never saw it and thus was frustrated as to why the puzzle made no sense. Thats on me, but I probably would have liked the puzzles more if they were actually realistic. [spoiler]For example: at the beginning of the game when you need a soda to short circuit the wiring in the refriderator room; I didn't realize putting in some random and crushed coin into the vending machine would get me the soda. I couldn't go back to get it because the boards over the spike pit had fallen. And there were perfectly fine liquids in the room. Why couldn't I have just used one of them?[/spoiler] Anyways, the puzzles were not always consistent with the objects you could use to complete them. I personally didn't find the puzzles to be realistic at times (not that this game is meant to be real of course)

Horror: There weren't any parts that I felt scared or surprised. The environment had good horror elements, but I could always see enemies coming and never really felt any danger unless I couldn't solve a puzzle fast enough. But the death trial and error system helped bme to not worry about death. Simply put, the game wasn't really scary. Just dark and spooky maybe. 

Graphics: Its an older game so I didn't expect anything great. I am sure it looked fine when it came out. The graphics aren't detrimental to enjoying the game.

As I said at the beginning of this review, I didn't find the game to be enjoyable or fun. The story evolved in a way that didn't make much sense since there was no foreshadowing of it in the first game. There were some links of course such as the "infection" it self, but I think it all fell flat by the end. I guess if the game goes on sale and you don't have any better options available, it is not that expensive and will provide a few hours of gameplay. There are many positive reviews, so you may enjoy the game. If you are looking for a solid horror game, this is not it. It is important to note that the devs did make substantial improvements in these areas in Amnesia: The Dark Descent.

So a quick "review". PROs and CONs first. Then some comments & random notes I have about the game.

[h1]PROs:[/h1]
+Puzzles
+Story
+Horrid combat removed
+Fun "side-kick"

[h1]CONs:[/h1]
-horror pretty much gone

[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[spoiler]There was a damsel in distress... who promised me a big hug if I save her. But I couldn't get my hug from my waifu. Instead I crushed her head (cuz she was actually bald, ugly futa. - she became alien)[/spoiler]
[b]Penumbra: run from nekkid aliens the puzzle edition.[/b]

[h1]Comments:[/h1]
Isn't really much to say. It's pretty much direct sequel to Overture. They removed that awful combat (thank god to that). This game included a lot of walking around in research facility, solving puzzles and solving the whole "issue" the story presented us.

Horror element is almost nonexistent here. All you get is few hallucinations (and minor jumpscares from them) and some naked phallus aliens chasing you. (which really.. you can just run through them and use painkillers (if you have them)... if don't feel like sneaking) 

So I would recommend this games who enjoy puzzles and story, rather than for horror fans who would expect spooks from this game. Or I would recommend this game to people who can't handle horror (as this has really minimal "horror")

[b]More puzzle, less horror.[/b]

[h1]7/10[/h1]

22985167.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague on jatko-osa Penumbra: Overturelle. Ja se on ottanut paljon oppia ykkösosasta.

ÄÄNIEFEKTIT/MUSIIKKI:
Penumbra: Black Plaguen äänimaailma on paljon edeltäjäänsä ahdistavampi. Musiikki on hermostuttavaa ja ääniefektit uskottavia. Ääninäyttely on hyvää.

TARINA:
¤Sisältää juonipaljastuksia¤
Penumbra: Black Plague jatkaa ensimmäisen osan tarinaa suoraan siitä, mihin se jäi. Päähenkilö Philip herää lukitusta huoneesta, tutkimuskeskuksesta syvällä maan alla. Hän onnistuu pakenemaan sellistään ja joutuu matkaamaan läpi kaaoksessa olevan tutkimuslaitoksen, vältellen zombimaisia olioita. Tämän lisäksi yksi zombimielistä, Clarence-niminen olio, on tunkeutunut Philipin päähän eikä tämä kieroutunut paskiainen tee tilanteesta yhtään helpompaa.
¤Juonipaljastukset päättyvät¤
Penumbra: Black Plaguen tarina menee hyvin yhteen edeltäjänsä kanssa, vastaten tyydyttävästi moniin kysymyksiin. Tarinassa on myös hetkiä, jotka järkyttävät hyvinkin pahasti. Tarina on tunnelmallinen ja hyvin kirjoitettu.

KAUHU:
Penumbra: Black Plague on paljon edeltäjäänsä pelottavampi. Viholliset ovat painajaismaisia ja ne karmaisevat koko pelin ajan. Peli onnistuu myös pitämään jännitystä yllä paljon edeltäjäänsä paremmin.

PELIMEKANIIKKA:
Penumbra: Black Plaguen pelimekaniikka on samanlainen kuin Penumbra: Overturessa, tosin sillä eroavaisuudella ettei pelaaja pysty taistelemaan vihollisiaan vastaan. Tämä lisää kauhun tunnetta huomattavasti ja pitää viholliset pelottavina. Joitakin vipuja on kuitenkin hankala kääntää tai venttiileitä pyörittää, saaden kontrollit tuntumaan tökeröltä.

GRAFIIKKA:
Pelin grafiikka on hyvä vuoden 2008 peliksi, ja siinä on pieniä parannuksia ykkösosaan katsottuna.

UUDELLEENPELUUARVO:
Penumbra: Black Plague vei itseltäni pelata läpi 4 tuntia. Uudelleenpeluuarvoa ei tosin tämän jälkeen enää ole.

TUNNELMA:
Penumbra: Black Plaguen tunnelma on todella ahdistava, ja peli onnistuu pitämään sen loppuun saakka.

YHTEENVETO:

Plussat:
+ Ääniefektit
+ Tarina
+ Pelottavat viholliset
+ Pelimekaniikka
+ Grafiikka
+ Tunnelma

Miinukset:
- Välillä töksähtelevät kontrollit
- Uudelleenpeluuarvo

22564544.review:
[b]Penumbra: Black Plague[/b] – это один из тех случаев, когда сиквел повторяет успех оригинала, а в некоторых моментах даже опережает. После удачной первой части, [b]Frictional Games[/b] с большим энтузиазмом, начинают работать над продолжением, что вполне очевидно. Вышла она в 2008 году и в очередной раз доказала, что для хорошей и качественной игры не нужны огромные вложения. Сыграл я в нее примерно в том же году. И она, на удивление, мне понравилась больше, чем оригинал. Но обо всем по порядку:

- В игре, так же как и в первой части, особое внимание уделено физике тел и детальному взаимодействию с предметами. Все осталось на том же уровне. Интерактивность никуда не делась. Тот же движок [b]HPL Engine[/b] вместе с поддержкой физического движка [b]«Newton»[/b] демонстрирует отличную физику, которая и сейчас впечатляет. Головоломок с применением физики стало больше, что, конечно же, радует. Хотя я прекрасно помню, как в свое время я чуть ли ни бился башкой об монитор, раз за разом застревая на каком-то месте.

- Атмосфера в игре осталась прежней и она никуда не делась. Творчество Лавкрафта находит отражение и здесь, что не мудрено. Ведь отсылок к великому американскому писателю намного больше, чем в первой части. Чувство напряжённости и страха не отпускают до самого конца. Все эти звуки и шорохи переданы безупречно. Но в отличие от первой части, здесь делается упор именно на пугающих и напряженных моментах, нежели на квестовую составляющую. Когда на тебя бежит очередной Джигурда с арматурой, как-то не до шуток. В общем, атмосфера оригинала сохранена.

- Графика со времен первой части не изменилась. Но она смотрелась вполне неплохо по меркам тех лет. Сейчас, конечно же, все это устарело. В глаза так и прут низкокачественные текстуры и модели персонажей, угловатые контуры объектов, но все это компенсируется грамотным освещением, игрой теней и шикарным гейм-дизайном уровней, как и в первой части. Хотя некоторые объекты (типа лазеров) детализированы отлично. Но знаете, мне на графику, наплевать. Я не сужу игру по внешней обертке. Для [b]Penumbra[/b] главное не графика, а атмосфера и геймплей, чего у нее не отнять.

- Геймплей игры практически не изменился. Главный герой так же изучает местность, ищет различные предметы, с которыми он будет взаимодействовать, смотрит в блокнот и откладывает кирпичи в темноте. Но самый главный плюс в этой части, это то, что игрока сделали полностью безоружным. И это, по моему мнению, было правильным решением. Если вы играли в первую часть, то поймете о чем я. Из-за нищебродского бюджета местный экшен там реализован очень криво и через ж..пу, видимо разрабы все-таки поняли, что экшен здесь ни к месту и убрали его. Как по мне, лучше все-таки безоружным ползать в темноте рачком и бочком, изучая местность и знакомясь с предками Джигурды.

- Отдельно хочется сказать о местном дубляже. Звучит он вполне неплохо. Особенно постарались с голосом Кевина (кто играл, тот поймет). Голосов здесь не так много, но каждый из них запомнится. Единственный непонятный момент – это голос станции. В оригинале он женский, а здесь какого-то х..я он мужской. Но это я что-то к мелочи прикопался. На сюжет и атмосферу он не влияет, но все-таки…

- Про сюжет я подробно рассказывать не буду, ибо спойлер, а это грех. Скажу только, что история, рассказанная в этой части, довольно интересно и грамотно вписывается в события из оригинала. С первых минут игра очень сильно интригует и затягивает, не отпуская до самых титров. В игре опять же не так много персонажей, но каждый из них запомнится, и преподнесёт вам немало сюрпризов. Врагов здесь, как у нас хороших дорог, то бишь не так много. Самый главный из них один, особь мужского пола (хм, видимо женщин на станции вообще не было), который неплохо так пощекочет вам нервы и будет сниться в кошмарах. Игра намного короче оригинала и проходится за 3-4 часа, что лично для меня – небольшой минус. Хотя некоторые головоломки заставят ваш пукан медленно гореть в огне.

   [b]Penumbra: Black Plague[/b] получилась отличной и проработанной игрой. Здесь есть и хороший интригующий сюжет, и, пропитанная творчеством Лавкрафта, атмосфера, и затягивающий геймплей. В общем, [b]Frictional Games[/b] создала очередную годноту. С первого взгляда может показаться, что игра не изменилась. Да, в некоторых аспектах она осталась прежней, но это даже хорошо, ведь это дань уважения предыдущей игре серии, чего не скажешь о следующей части. Но это уже отдельный разговор.

[i]9 хороших сиквелов из 10, ностальгия.[/i]

22555166.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague Gold Edition включает в себя Penumbra: Black Plague и расширение Penumbra: Requiem 
Загнанный в темный подземный комплекс, бесстрашный исследователь Филипп полон решимости узнать правду об исчезновении своего отца. 
Окруженный врагами и ужасом со всех сторон, Филипп должен собрать все подсказки и сложить их воедино, одновременно ведя борьбу со внутренним голосом и галлюцинациями.
Сможет ли Филипп побороть свой страх и раскрыть тайну, которая преследовала его всю жизнь? Решать вам… 
Современный движок игры, поддерживающий современное 3D и технологии физики. Адаптированная система размытого изображения и новая усовершенствованная система освещения, работающая в режиме реального времени, позволяет еще глубже окунуться в атмосферу психологического ужаса. 
Увлекательный и детально проработанный сюжет. Поиск ключей к разгадке тайны исчезновения отца Филиппа на протяжении всей игры открывают новые подробности произошедшего и придают истории законченный вид. 
Высокая степень взаимодействия с окружающей средой. Вы можете взаимодействовать с любым объектом, не прикованным к земле! Сфокусируйтесь на объекте, поднимите и переместите его с помощью мыши. 
Атмосферное звуковое сопровождение. Различные звуки усиливают атмосферу и дают игроку подсказки о надвигающейся опасности.

Моя оценка 10/10.

22361741.review:
[b]Penumbra: Black Plague[/b] is the second and longest official installment of the Penumbra horror epic. It begins immediately after the end of [url=steamcommunity.com/id/evilTak/recommended/22180]Penumbra: Overture[/url], with the protagonist, Philip, awakening in a locked cell, having been incapacitated by an unknown entity. 

Black Plague fills in the sketch of the story begun in Overture, eventually unveiling the truth of the hidden facility disguised as a mine in northern Greenland, the method behind the madness of its inhabitants, both human and bestial, and finally Philip's father's dark secret.

The game far surpasses its predecessor in the vastly increased level of terrifying surreal elements: in Overture, I was mainly running from spiders, hiding from mutant wolves, and being stalked by a madman. By contrast, in Black Plague[spoiler]I waded through pools of blood to manipulate monstrous forearms growing from the walls and was forced into hallucinatory visions by a foulmouthed mental hitchhiker while fleeing for my life from disease-infested monstrosities.[/spoiler]

Gameplay-wise, Black Plague keeps the best aspects of Overture, and improves, refines, or discards the worse. All of the immersive, horrifying elements that made the first game an indie hit are maintained, along with environment-oriented puzzles and physical interaction via manual manipulation; Overture's clumsy combat mechanic has been completely removed in favor of more trap-based encounters with hostile creatures. 

By modern standards, the game is a bit graphically dated, but the writing and the ambience were more than enough to keep me fully immersed ([i]and fully tensed[/i]) as I explored the hallways of the facility and the dark passages of Philip's mind.

Penumbra: Black Plague is a psychological horror classic, and I recommend it to all fans of the genre.

21790640.review:
Penumbra Black Plague - сиквел к первой части. Прямое продолжение истории Overture. Игра начинается в том месте, где неожиданно и очень таинственно закончился предыдущий эпизод. При этом, интрига концовки первой части и некоторые тайны, секреты, остаются неизвестными ещё до половины игры. Пожалуй, именно во втором эпизоде сюжет раскрывается полностью. В данной части узнаешь и получаешь ответы на многие вопросы. И складывается уже общая картина об произошедшей катастрофе на станции и роли главного героя в ней. Игра полна различных развилок и неожиданный поворотов. Этим она и цепляет. В каждой последующей важной сценке, всё оборачивается так, как мы, не могли бы и подумать. К тому же, в игре появилось несколько "живых" персонажей, что в свою очередь делает сюжетную линию более разветвлённой. В отличие от первой части, где преимущественно история рассказывалась из листочков и бумажек, в этой всё происходит в реальном времени. В общем, в плане сюжета игра очень прибивала. Отдельная благодарность разработчикам, за непредсказуемость и столь интересное развитие событий.

Геймплей остался практически таким же, за исключение некоторых деталей, а именно. Были убраны практически все виды монстров, присутствовавших в первой части. Но ввели новый вид, который не только кардинально отличался от зомби собак, но и изменил подход к игре и способы её прохождения. Так же убрали всю систему боя и соответственно оружие. Теперь оно присутствует лишь в инвентаре, исключительно как орудие, для решения головоломок. Исходя из этого, от врагов мы можем только убежать, либо спрятаться, в следтсвии чего, главный герой становится очень слабым, уязвимым и беззащитным. Теперь уже приходится внимательно смотреть по сторонам и прислушиватся к подозрительным звукам.

Помимо прекрасного сюжета, игра стала намного более пугающей и страшной. Вот это действительно настоящий хоррор, с гнетущей атмосферой страха и ужаса. В игре много моментов, которые действительно могут испугать, ну или хотя бы заставить вас взволноватся.
Поскольку дейтсвия игры перекочевали с Заброшеной Шахты в Исследовательскую Лабораторию, то карты стали намного красивей и более атмосферными. И если сама схема игры осталось той же(бродим по перекрёсным коридорам и комнатам в поисках нужных предметов, для открытия следующий двери), то разнообразие локаций и головоломок стало на порядок выше и качественней. Во втором эпизоде, упор на различные логические задачки, сделан ещё больше. Практически в каждой следующей комнате, нам попадаются всё новые и новые головоломки. Многие из них сложны и требуют от вас смекалки, заставляя думать немного не стандартно. Но при этом задачки правдоподобны и логичны. Как и в первой части, можно надолго застрять в одном месте, не зная что делать дальше. И когда находишь решение понимаешь, насколько было просто и трудно в тоже время. Ну и конечно же не стоит упускать важные моменты из своих записей, там хранятся не менее ценные подсказки.
Теперь же инвентарь стал более практичным и сбалансированым. Если раньше, мы могли спокойно пройти весь эпизод используя лишь фонарик, то теперь роль зажигательных факелов и неоновой лампы выросли вдвое, втрое.

Средняя графика с текстурами низкого качества, но с грамотной и предельно хорошей работой света. Игра мрачная и тёмная сама по себе, но в игре прекрасное освещение, хорошо сделаны различные визуальные эффекты, наподобие лучей и теней. Улучшена анимация, теперь враги двигаются более плавно, но не очёнь качество самих моделей.
Хороший, мрачный саундтрек и прекрасная озвучка персонажей.

В итоге получаем хоррор головоломку, с интересным сюжетом, атмосферными локациями и своеобразным геймплеем. Прекрасное продолжение серии и истории.

Оценка: 10/10

游戏总共11章，而我在10章末卡到道具bug，7瓶混合物少一瓶，已在可以走的全部区域翻箱倒柜地找了一遍，影子都没见，因此断定是bug，虽然烦归烦，但是离通关也就剩一点动画剧情+追捕了，应该足以评测。

+：剧情先避之不提，这游戏可玩性简直碉堡，音效好评，不像某面条man，只有魔性的混乱噪音，这个能听到主角的心跳声及喘气声，代入感不错，接着是物理效果，不愧是失忆症的工作室Frictional出品的，这在该作中绝大部分的物体都能提起来，并且可以自由旋转360°，画面很精细，场景没有多华丽但作为恐怖游戏已足够。另外惊悚度和压抑感恰到好处，适合较多人群游玩。

-：解密略难，主要体现在很多地方不是正常玩法的玩家能想到的，也托这物理效果的福，比如正常玩法：开门找钥匙呗，开电线盒找螺丝刀呗，而这游戏是地上捡块砖往电线盒上砸，当时我就想发泄一下，一砸就傻眼了...而且这游戏还有叠高高理念，就不细说了。有些细节口味很重，关卡设计天马行空，简单来说就是制作人脑袋有hole。

总：感觉把bug补补，口味稍轻点，离佳作就差临门一脚了，不懂作者的想法。不过尽管如此它依然是款制作精良的好游戏。

Great puzzles (I cite the radio puzzle as the best I've seen in a game) and a lonesome, oppressive atmosphere (the setting is ripe for a horror tale) make this game a must for horror fans. For those unfamiliar with the genre it might be a bit of a dive into the deep end due to the clunky combat and the resultant emphasis on hiding rather than fighting. 
The physics engine adds a lot to the game, making it stick out a bit amongst its peers (especially for its time) as you can pick up items and place/throw them as you wish. This is primarily utilized for puzzles and creating obstacles to hide from enemies. 
The story doesn't go too far in this entry, mostly setting the scene for the sequel. It's worth experiencing, as it leads to something a bit more profound than what we're used to seeing in most horror titles.

It's certainly very up there as far as Survival Horror is concerned.

20863677.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague is basically a prototype version of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. This is not a criticism; just know that if you are coming hot off of Amnesia there will be some steps backward.

Having gotten rid of the ability to fight back in Overture, Frictional Games makes a much more frightening game in Black Plague. The enemies you encounter in Black Plague are gross-looking, cannot be killed, and sometimes carry light sources to see you in the dark. Unfortunately, they are also dumb as rocks and there are plenty of objects you can jump on top of, safely out of reach, and look around to solve your predicament. At one point, I managed to glitch a mattress in a doorway to keep a monster out of the room I was in.

Without spoiling too much, there are plenty of moments that made me jump or feel uncomfortable and the plot balances "scary heeby-jeebies" with actual plot development, letting the horror set in by implications of the happenings around you rather than the monsters you find haunting you.

Overall, Black Plague is a vast improvement over Overture and from a design perspective, it's interesting to see how Frictional Games went from that game on to their more popular game, Amnesia. If you like Overture, Black Plague is better. If you like Amnesia, give the Penumbra series a shot (and check out the fan-made Penumbra mods for Amnesia; they take place after the official Penumbra games).

20492794.review:
[h1][b]A long one coming through[/b][/h1]

Overture and especially Black Plague are, in my opinion, the most worthy horror games out there. And that comes from a person who has played quite a lot of those.
Personally for me this game even beats Amnesia: The Dark Descent in the matter of story and atmosphere.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story indeed is brilliant. It feels realistic, makes you truly involved in it.
Every event has a cause and a detailed explanation. A very interesting one, too.
Like in Amnesia: The Dark Descent, the story is uncovered through the collection of notes and pages from diaries.
There are also certain heartbreaking twists in both games, possibly the reason of my massive attraction.

[h1]Atmosphere[/h1]
Reminds Amnesia, but placed at a more recent time, with more real problems at hand.
Instead of a lantern you have a flashlight, a glow stick and flares. The flashlight also requires batteries to work. Instead of darkness and ancient spirits, you have scientific research facilities and deadly viruses. In the first game you are also able to hold and use several weapons.

[h1]Scares[/h1]
No jumpscares, only enemy AI. In the first game this is mostly undead dogs, and in the second game - something yet more interesting. The chase can mostly be avoided if one's good with stealth. Not always, however.
The game is quite scary, but it mostly comes from the atmosphere.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Well-done. No casualizing, there's full item interactions, descriptions; flashlight batteries are present. The gameplay is understandable and simple, while keeping the game challenging.
In many ways it reminds Amnesia: The Dark Descent, except for the lack of sanity bar.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
A good choice for anyone interested in a good exciting story, engaging atmosphere.
For those who like scary spooky games - it's yours as well.
However, if you are not interested in reading notes and absorbing the story throughout the game - you might as well enjoy something different.

20462313.review:
The developers cut the disappointing parts of Overture (combat and weak/confusing story) and added an impressive amount of depth and plot on top of the existing foundation.

This game is an exciting narrative with mostly interesting physical puzzles sprinkled throughout.  A couple of the puzzles felt tedious to me, particularly towards the end.  I didn't find the story to be particularly profound, though.  

Even more dissapointingly, I had hoped more than anything that the game would build on the immersive, horrific atmosphere of the first episode, and genuinely creep me out even more, in the same way that SOMA did.  I found that the game fell well short of this.  Maybe it was Penumbra saturation, but this episode hardly felt like a horror game at all.  For 2008 tech, the world and graphics are spectacular and hold up well, but it felt like a video game and not the horrifying universe I wanted to wade into for a few hours.

Fricitional -- as ever -- gets my strongest recommendation for a fun, thoughtful game that emphasizes story, atmosphere, and puzzles above shooting guns for 5 hours.

20458299.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague picks up where Penumbra: Overture left off, but with a mild twist; you're playing as Philip from the first game again, but this time, the game is presented as a flashback. After discovering what became of Philip at the end of Overture, we find he has an entirely new set of problems to deal with, and as it turns out, they're much larger in scale. This time around, Philip is joined by a voice in his head that goes by the name Clarence, who simultaneously makes things feel a bit less lonely and increases the general menace of this new realm to explore.

Set mostly in an underground bunker of sorts, Black Plague is a welcome change of pace from all the rocks, rocks, and more rocks of the first game, but has equally ingenious puzzles and challenges to its predecessor, albeit with more modern tools and components at your disposal. This time around, encounters with enemies are a bit more frequent as well, and given the higher intelligence of the area's enemies, these encounters are also a bit more frustrating.

Despite being slightly more annoying and less looming-fear-based, Black Plague goes a long way toward explaining what's going on in Penumbra's setting, and what set off the events that drove Philip underground in the first place. The explanation for the primary force in motion is tied into real-world folklore as well, adding a tinge of realism to an otherwise fantastical situation and making it feel uncomfortably close to home.

Interacting with the world around you and the world itself both feel a bit more polished this time around, with visual upgrades to all your environments and a more responsive set of controls. Music in the game tends toward the ambient end of things and is well-placed, managing not to step on Black Plague's excellent sound design. While it seems to be the standard for horror games, do try to play this with headphones (or really good surround sound) to get the full impact of the audio, as it's clear they put quite a bit of work into it.

Included with Black Plague is Penumbra: Requiem, a puzzle-centric expansion of sorts that ties up a bunch of loose ends still dangling from the first two games while not quite being the third entry in the trilogy Frictional intended. Despite its short length, it's a good end to the series, and finishes the Penumbra games' slide from the real to the absolutely surreal.

20446032.review:
ホラーアドベンチャーゲーム。
父ハワードの失踪の原因を探るフィリップの探索は続き、父が何をしていたのか、シェルターで何が起きたのか、自分の身がどうなってしまうのかが明らかにされていく。
Penumbra3部作の2作目。前作からストーリーは続いているが、前作はあくまで序章に過ぎず主人公が探索するきっかけさえ知っておけば問題なくプレイできると思われる。前作よりも大幅に演出面が強化されホラーゲームとしての完成度が上がっている。また、操作性にも若干の改善が見られる。

登場するクリーチャーが主に白い人型のクリーチャーに変わっており、前作の犬とは異なり索敵をしっかりと行ってくるのでステルスプレイの意義が出ているのは良かったと思う。今作では戦うことができないことも改善の1つだ。ただし、このクリーチャーは足が遅くしつこくないので、前作の犬と同様に[spoiler]走って逃げることで簡単に振り切れる[/spoiler]のが残念だ。

演出の強化と適度なイベントがあり前作で感じられた単調さは薄れ、前作よりも謎解きはタイミングがシビアなものが少なくなっているために雰囲気に没頭できるようになっているのは良かった。ただ、自分の中のもうひとりの自分クラレンスは、煽りセリフがひたすら鬱陶しいだけで、ゲームの雰囲気を損ねている感じがしてならなかった。
また、ゲーム途中の問題解決能力うんぬんの話や複数の自分など、"Bioshock"のような主人公フィリップとプレイヤーをリンクさせるストーリー要素があると予想はしていたが、予想を超えた展開が待っていてゲーム起動時のメッセージがそのままラストに繋がっているのは良かった。

前作よりも大幅に進化しておりホラーゲームとして良作に仕上がっている。古いゲームのために古さは感じられるが、先の展開が気になるストーリー運びと意外性のある展開、雰囲気作りの良さは十分にあり、ホラーゲームが好きならオススメのゲームだ。

20224325.review:
After the disappointment that was Penumbra Overture, although I acknowledge it was an introduction to Black Plague, this game is indeed what Penumbra is all about. Having played Amnesia before, I believe this game feels fundamentally very similar, such as a parallel game (gameplay and mechanics are exactly the same) and at the same time very different (story, context and purpose). 

In this game there is an immediate sense of danger, there is no way to avoid enemies other than outsmart them, thinking fast and finding a solution right when they suddenly appear before you (while scarying the crap out of you). Also, you are CONSTANTLY solving puzzles. There is no way you can progress without solving a puzzle in the current room, every section of the game is a maze and requires going to point A to get item X to go back and open door B. and while you are going back the monsters come in. 

The story is where this game falls short. The motivation of this game is finding out what happened to the character's father, it is unknown if he is still alive. While you are at that, you get infected by an intelligent virus that talks to you (annoys you mostly) and can blurry your vision, confuse you, etc. That virus character is so annoying that made me really hate him and wish it was quickly over. Also, from Penumbra Overture I was expecting a different explanation to the existance of all those monsters, and it turned out to be a very different thing.

Still, for horror game fans, it is an interesting experience, not superior to Amnesia, but fun nonetheless.

19538113.review:
The Black Plague is a significantly shorter game (no more than five hours, generally) than it's predecessor, Overture.

However, it's brevity is compensated by substantially more story and answers to players' burning questions on what the hell is happening in game.

Penumbra: Black Plague still suffers from a lack of variety in monsters and challenges, though the enemy is far scarier than the models used for Overture. The Penumbra series in general is quite lacking in versatility and diversity of puzzles and challenges, but nevertheless makes for a very interesting adventure.

I would recommend playing the first game to get the full story, but to be completely honest, Overture does not provide much at all to the story of the overall series, and Black Plague could be played alone with the majority of the themativ understanding still intact.

Bottom line: The series in general has a brilliant story, but being an older game, suffers from repetitive puzzles and challenges. Overture lacked these excellent story elements, and Black Plague, while scarier and more immersive, was shorter and yet more repetitive. Together, the experience is fascinating albeit simple.

19382438.review:
This review comes from someone who played Amnesia before any Penumbra game, so make of that what you will. I'll try to keep this short.

I'll start off by saying that, on the technical side, the game is pretty darn good. The engine itself (as evidenced by its use in more recent games by Frictional) holds up very well to this day. Black Plague was released in 2008, so it's not incredibly old, but, in an age where I have to check whether or not entirely new games will actually run on my specific combination of hardware, I haven't had any trouble in the slightest getting the game to run. No crashes, no graphics issues, no slowdowns, nothing like that at all. The only problem that I have with it in that regard is that you can't change the FOV, but that's set [i]just[/i] high enough for it to not be a problem for me, at least.

A lot of the game revolves around physics-based puzzles and they've definitely put enough effort in to make sure that the physics engine works as perfectly as it should do. Objects feel like they weigh as much as they should, moving objects around isn't a chore and the game knows when you want to put an item in a specific place and locks it there without any hastle or feeling like it's doing your work for you.

On the subject of puzzles, for the most part, they work well enough. The solutions are invariably completely intuative (no, you're not going to tie a balloon to a banana and feed it to a monster to get that computer running, you're going to find working drives and format them), and, on the off chance that the answer is simplified a little so that it doesn't get in the way of the game mechanics, it still makes perfect sense and there's a way to find out how to do it. As someone who frequently gets frustrated with adventure/puzzle games and has to turn the Internet off so that I don't cave and look up the answers (i.e. an idiot), I figured everything out for myself pretty quickly, save for one puzzle near the beginning which made sense in retrospect. The only problem I have with the puzzles is that many require finding multiple specific items, and, without fail, every one of them will be hidden behind a couple of other physics objects that are stacked in an odd and very conspicuous way.

Now, unfortunately, there are two very big issues that I had with the game that, while they weren't quite enough to stop me from playing, they are bad enough to me that I wouldn't personally recommend the game. The first is the story: the story of Penumbra: Overture, while not groundbreaking, was at least intriguing and subtle enough that it kept me very invested through the whole game. In Black Plague, that subtlety goes right out of the window from the beginning when it gives you a very clear and safe view of the new monster, then, sometime later, the player character develops an internal voice in his head whose main purpose seems to be to explain every plot point several times over in case you didn't pick up the hints. There were several times when I read something interesting in a note and got as far as thinking "I wonder if that means-", then he'd immediately chime in and say that that's exactly what it means, please don't try to work it out for yourself. It honestly feels like Frictional realised that they could afford voice actors for this one and just decided to throw in literally anything that they could think for them to say, no matter how dumb or obvious, on top of the quality of the voice acting giving Bethesda a run for its money. I also counted four times in the first hour or so where the player character had the [i]exact same[/i] realisation about himself. Add in how, for some reason, they decided to throw in an almost constant barrage of downright embarrassing attempts at humour (seriously, one computer asked if I was sure that I wanted to do something, then if I was [i]really[/i] sure, then if I was [i]really really[/i] sure...) and I got to the point where I just couldn't consider this a horror game anymore.

On that note, my other problem with it is that it really doesn't feel like a horror game in almost any respect. It's very dark (lighting-wise), yes, but... that's really it. It doesn't take long to realise that you're in almost no danger whatsoever. I think that I came across four things in the entire game that were able to hurt me, disregarding an obvious tripwire "puzzle", and the very few enemies that you do encounter can be outrun, avoided, sneaked around and generally outsmarted with no effort at all. I appreciate the rudimentary stealth mechanics as a massive fan of the Thief series, but the enemies in Black Plague are exactly as intelligent as the dogs in Penumbra: Overture, which is to say not too bright.

In conclusion, I suppose that, if you just want puzzles and can appreciate something of an adventure/puzzle game in first person (some mechanics actually brought back memories of classic point-and-click games, but much better-polished), and can also tune out the excuse plot for those to exist, then I can definitely recommend the game because I enjoyed those parts a decent amount. If you're looking for a compelling horror experience, then, as far as I'm concerned, you're probably not going to find it here, although I've met people with a completely different opinion to mine. I'll also note that it's pretty short; it took me slightly over six hours to finish, but you get the entire Penumbra series for £7 at full price, so that's absolutely more than fair for that length.

18557901.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague is a sequel to Penumbra: Overture, an adventure horror game with more realistic physics for more immersive interaction. It was released in 2008, year after original, and yep, still made by Frictional Games, but this time under different publishers. They say that under pressure from old publisher Frictional Games turned what was intented to be trilogy into duology, Black Plague concluding the series. It's unknown how much from planned two last episodes was fit into Black Plague, it could be possible that something important got cut. Thus some people belive the ending to be a slight cliffhanger and want Penumbra 3 to happen, while others just view it as a proper bad ending of sorts. I am leaning toward the latter.

You may notice that Steam store says "Gold Edition". It means that it includes Requiem, an expansion pack. Which you shouldn't think of as Penumbra 3, as it's just a set of puzzles that were cut from Black Plague without horror. Or big story. That, and maybe not cut, can't say for sure.

So, as far scary, it's a step up from Overture. Or step down. Now, instead of fighting it out with dogs, developers decided to remove weapons fully. Instead you will have the infected roam the corridors, who look like creepy zombies. And you will not be able to fight them directly, instead your only options is to hide and avoid them. Which is supposed to make it scarier. If forget that they aren't terribly efficient killers as you can just outrun them easily and not even bother with hiding sometimes. Oh well, always hiding would have been too annoying for me.

You aren't alone this time either, as the world feels more filled with other characters. Mostly human corpses that Overture lacked so much. But you will be accomplished by one sarcastic voice which isn't exactly enemy but not ally either. From one point it also brings in creepy hallucinations. Thankfully nothing that screams into your face. But then he and his sarcasm pop-up often enough that I can't help but to feel that at times game felt like a thriller with black humor rather than proper atmoshperic horror.

The story of the game on other hand is enough to make you play it not because of atmoshpere but to know what is going on and what happens next. It's not just about being alone and reading tons of notes. Things are happening right in front of you and plot twists around, as it finally get revelead and tells you slowly what is actually happening, while Overture was barely hinting at things. It was exciting. For horror-adventure.
Sounds and music were good at what they were supposed to do as well. Mostly tension. Sometimes paranoia. And sometimes relaxing in a locked little room, deep in a unknown.

Puzzles felt more refined as well. Or at least they felt more fitting into main flow. Still got a bunch of standard puzzles and puzzles that make you use said physics. And throwing bricks to break stuff. And combining inventory items. Even if slightly less experimental than original.

Black Plague is a much tighter dark narrative, much less about wandering in the dark alone, but still with nice atmoshpere and horror. A worthy conclusion to duology. Or main meat of it. Depends on preference.
By the way, if you find all 10 statues in the game then you will be given a password. You can use it to play a simple Space Invader-like game on one of the in-game computers. Or you can open game's folder and use it on super_secret archive to unlock bonus materials.

18528305.review:
[h1]Что заставляет человека двигаться вперёд? Стремление найти ответы на вопросы? Желание отыскать самого себя? Для Филиппа есть ещё одна причина - безысходность.[/h1]

[b]Харуки Мураками[/b] как-то писал: "[b][i]Если есть выход, то есть и вход. Так устроено почти все. Ящик для писем, пылесос, зоопарк, чайник... Но, конечно, существуют вещи, устроенные иначе. Например, мышеловка.". Это выражение как нельзя кстати подходит для описания Penumbra: Black Plague.[/i][/b]

Мы всё так же находимся на станции [b]"Мануик"[/b]. События первой части серии не прошли бесследно и герой приходит в себя где-то внутри научного комплекса. Ведомый желанием найти отца и выяснить, наконец, что же творится вокруг. Он продолжает своё движение к разгадке. Однако, как говорится, "за кривыми деревьями и леса не разглядишь".

Со времён [b][i]Overture[/i][/b] ситуациия на станции только ухудшилась. Больше проблем, загадок, героев и секретов. Вторая часть серии стала богаче в плане сюжета и действий, творящихся вокруг, но, увы, поплатилась за это продолжительностью. Всего 4 - 5 часов геймплея. 

К слову о геймплее, он полностью перекочевал из [b][i]Penumbra: Overture[/i][/b]. Мы всё так же будем собирать предметы и записки, решать загадки, прятаться в тенях и бегать от врагов. Атмосфера стала только лучше, а декорации заброшенной станции способствуют этому: скрипучие двери, системы охраны, изменившиеся "работники" и сам вирус Туурунгайт. Всё это наполняет 5 часов игры постоянно происходящими событиями, что даёт огромный плюс сюжетной составляющей. 

Не хочу углубляться в повествование и рассказывать вам про резкие повороты сюжета, что будут ждать каждого, кто вместе с [b]Филиппом[/b] решится на поиск ответов. Сделайте это. Apart from Amnesia, this is one of the few horror games I can actually recommend. 

The graphics are ok, but the sound is what makes the game extremely athmospheric. Controls are spot-on and easy, just like the inventory system. Also, the story is very good and overall, the game is a very enjoyable experience. 

The only thing which kinda annoyed me is the fact that the enemy AI is dumb. And I'm not talking about "sometimes dumb" but rather "full Donald Trump dumb". It makes the game way too easy if you've been spotted.

Anyhow, the game is still recommendable due to its story and gameplay. So go ahead and buy it! You won't regret it.

18382226.review:
Frictional made some terrible decisions involving the story, how it's told, and how the player interacts with the antagonists.

Edit: I didn't want to go into a lot of detail, but people are actually reading this review so I decided to elabroate a little.  There are also very few bad reviews, so hopefully this will give people a more rounded impression of the game before they buy it.  Also, I love Frictional and I can't wait for their next game.  The first Penumbra and Soma are excellent titles.

One of the main characters is supposed to be this really omnious dude but they got someone who sounds like Bernie Sander's (US politican wish a hard Brooklyn accent) greasy brother to do the voice acting--it's completely immersion breaking.  That character is also incredibly obnoxious, it's more like dealing with an annoying child instead of.. well, what it's supposed to be.  That might have been the point, but I don't know how keeping a metaphorical fruit fly around the character's ear is supposed to contribute to suspense.

The story went out of control toward the end, think sorta like M. Night Shyamalan.  Some people might like that; I think it's poor writing.  It's almost on the same level of bad as The Village.

There's no combat in the game, which can be a positive, but all of the enemies are just really weak and slow, so it turns out to be more of an annoyance.  They also put them in your face so much you just aren't afraid of them by the end.  Of course as the game progresses more and more show up, so it's just.. more and more annoying dudes that you have to dodge and weave..

The game has boss fights.  A story focused non combat game has boss fights.  They're as terrible as you can imagine.  There are also really gimmicky auto-kill areas in the game that don't entirely make sense.  It feels really jarring to go from being chased around by actual entities then in other parts just outright dying if you don't get the puzzle right or if you're mediocre at platforming.  That's not horror, especially with how dying is handled.  It just turns into a quickload cycle until you get things right.  While that might work in something like Silent HIll or Resident Evil, that's not good gameplay for a strictly story based horror game like Black Plague.

A lot of people really really like this game, and more power to them.  The game has a really cool atmosphere and the environment is interesting and creative.  Opinions are opinions, take what I have to say along with what everyone else is saying and come up with your own decision.  A lot of the fluff/extra parts of the game are really good, but the core--the story and how it's told--is awful.  That's why I don't recommend this game.

Edit: Added an actual review.

A fantastic game, it takes a step up from Overture by introducing two new characters and seamlessly contuining the story. 18193808.review:
Это отличное продолжение серии которое превосходит первую часть практически по всем пунктам.
Игра прям оживает, если например в первой части было местами скучно, одиноко, то тут скучать не приходится.
Тут у нас появляется ещё более интересный друг которой совсем даже весёлый, и харизматичный.
Итак, плюсы игры +

1. Мы получаем ещё более интересный живой сюжет чем в первой части.
2. Ещё более атмосферная музыка которая запоминается даже очень.
3. Более интересные локации.
4. Моменты когда наш персонаж ловит глюки, и буквально попадает в миры своего разума.
5. Более интересные загадки чем в первой части.
6. Мы получаем друга, и не одного которые собственно оживляют игру.
7. Атмосфера стала ещё лучше, более живой, и менее гнетущей.
8. Наш герой наконец не ломает конечности с метровой высоты.
9. Монстры стали меньше надоедать, и стали немного поинтересней.
10. Игра не вылетает даже с локализацией.

А теперь о минусах -

1.Оптимизация не идеальная, иногда бывают скачки с 60 до 30 кадров, и это на видеокарте GTX 980, но эти моменты происходят не так часто, но все же их наличие в такой игре удивляет ибо например у меня Metal Gear на ультра практически никогда не позволял себе проседать больше чем на 1 кадр из 60.
При включённой вертикальной синхронизации кажется дела обстоят ещё хуже, но примите к сведенью что я записывал видео на другой жесткий диск.

2. В этой игре нам не дают возможности убивать монстров, по-моему это связанно ещё с сюжетом, но все же странно что погружаясь глубже наш герой стал более безобидный, да и монстров стало меньше, тут игра меня вовсе не напрягает приходиться прятаться примерно 2 раза.
Этот минус вовсе не напрягает, но сам факт игра в этом плане похудела.

3. Ну а последний минус тот же самый что и в первой части, и я просто его скопирую сюда.
Нет никакой локализации что очень странно ведь некоторые загадки требуют хорошего знания языка, и учитывая что игру не покупают одни знающие английский язык, ещё учитывая продолжительность, возраст игры, цену наконец, то можно было потратится, и закинуть несколько языков, или хотя бы субтитры.
Для меня это не проблема, но не отнести такое к минусу игры из-за её тематики сложно.
Учитывая что существует локализации, но есть и баги из-за них - ну это же можно было подправить, в общем некрасиво получается.

В итоге мы получаем игру которая реально практически по всем пунктам лучше своей первой части.

Она даже более реиграбельна.

Однозначно рекомендую всем любителям атмосферных мрачных приключений...

Моя оценка игре 8.5 из 10

В игре куча разнообразных загадок,неплохая и атмосферная графика сделанная в стиле зернистой фотоплёнки.Сюжет в игре прост и понятен-разыскать своего отца и выбраться.Но не тут то было.ГГ ловят и садят в закрытую камеру из которой нам предстоит выбраться и начать расследование.По ходу игры герой познакомится с Аммабель,которая хочет помочь нам выбраться,но к середине игры будет обратное...

Also meiner Meinung nach ist eine gute Balance erreicht worden, so das auch "Action" in dem Spiel ist, nur das es halt kein reines Ballerspiel, sondern ein wirkliches Horror-Spiel geworden ist.

17379606.review:
Несмотря на то, что «Penumbra: Black Plague» как две капли воды похож на предшественника, сиквел вышел не хуже оригинала и смог сюжетно ответить на многие вопросы, которые могли возникнуть после первой игры.

Геймплей в игре практически не изменился, и всё также представляет из себя прятки от монстров по углам. Разве что оружия под рукой в виде молотка или кирки, у главного героя отныне нет, и из-за этого выживать становиться ещё тяжелее. 

Левел-дизайн претерпел изменения, и отныне вместо лабиринтов старых шахт, у нас имеются такие-же лабиринты старого исследовательского комплекса учёных, которых, как и главного героя привело сюда любопытство. 

Головоломки упростились, и зачастую всё строиться не на использовании физики или логики, а на банальном использовании рычагов и ключей.

Другое дело, что авторам удалось нагнать жути в игре куда больше, чем это было «Penumbra: Overture». Главного героя помимо новых видов противников, регулярно мучают и всякого-рода галлюцинации, ощущения Дежавю, а атмосфера опасности даёт о себе знать в сопоставлении всей картины происходящего. Благодаря этому на протяжении всей игры, ты испытываешь тревогу и панику от невозможности предугадать, что ждёт тебя дальше, а под конец ты и вовсе теряешься в экзистенциальном кошмаре.

Вторая часть «Penumbra» подняла планку хоррора и жуткой атмосферы на новый уровень, и проходить мимо этой игры нельзя ни в коем случае. Хотя-бы ради концовки в духе творений Лавкрафта, которая сильно удивит игрока.

Продолжение одного из лучших хорроров последних лет - после того, как мы оказываемся за желеной дверью, оставив шахты позади - игра преображается, изменилось всё и окружение и гейиплей, нет - механика осталась той же, но теперь у нас в голове есть подселенец с чёрным юморком, который может влиять на наше восприятие действительности, собаки и пауки уступили место мутантам, при виде которых ГГ плохеет (это получило дальнейшее развитие в Амнезии), теперь мы больше не можем никого убивать, такак оружия у нас нет, задачек стало больше, они стали разнообразней и интересней.

Здесь больше общения - в прошлой части нас вёл Рыжий, в этой Амабель и Кевин (который заслуживает отдельной похвалы за те коленца, что он выдаёт), в этой части больше упора на сюжет и раскрытия тайн, а также головоломки, но она такая же страшная, как и прошлая часть, они страшные каждая по-своему и я даже не могу какая из них в этом плане лучше, впрочем планка качества у второй намного выше в плане проработки и исполнения, оно и понятно первая была считай демонстрацией возможностей команды разработчиков
Интересно изучать записки, разбираясь в происходящем, решать задачки, подкидываемые игрой, импользуя всё, что попадёт под руку. И самое главное - [b]играть нуютно[/b], постоянно  оборачиваешься на любой шорох, а громкий стук в дверь вызывает уже самую настоящую панику. Если вы любитель пощикотать себе нервы и не играли в Пенумбру - нужно в срочном порядке исправить сей недостаток, это классика.

16833839.review:
While writing this review, I found it hard to write it without just saying "It's Penumbra: Overture, but without the hit-or-miss combat system and with more reasons to be frightened of the world." Because that's precisely what Penumbra: Black Plague is. It's the example of what a successor should be. It sticks to what worked in the original and removes what players didn't like. For example, Penumbra: Black Plague maintains the terrifying atmosphere and adventure game elements of Penumbra: Overture, but removes the (overly reviled) combat system. There was also some new additions, with one specific addition being a character that constantly messes with Philip's mind (and by connection, the player's mind).

Anyway, continuing without connecting it to Penumbra: Overture, Penumbra: Black Plague is just a excellent horror game, and the clear step toward Amnesia: The Dark Descent. The game starts off immediately, with only a brief cutscene explaining the prior events. From that point, Penumbra: Black Plague is practically a nonstop horror show of twists, turns, evil science, hallucinations, and an ancient evil. As cliched as I'm making it sound, the whole of the story is highly creative, with an increased atmosphere as well. It's just as terrifying as Penumbra: Overture, if not slightly more. The removal of combat helps, along with enemies that won't give up the chase and hallucinations that constantly make you question reality. As for the gameplay, the removal of combat makes Penumbra: Black Plague feel identical to the classic adventure games of the 1990s, such as Tex Murphy and Myst. It's a change that is highly welcome, as it becomes amplified with decent exploration, hidden collectibles, and great puzzles. It's a very tense and terrifying game with a great story and more than decent visuals.

Penumbra: Black Plague Gold Edition also gives you Penumbra: Requiem, a small expansion pack to Penumbra: Black Plague. The expansion is decent for the most part, trading the old-school adventure approach with gameplay more akin to Portal. The puzzles do mesh well with the gameplay, creating some intricate, multi-part puzzles.  However, the atmosphere is pretty much gone here and, while still occasionally eerie, it's not nearly as terrifying as the original two games. The story does try to tie up all of the loose ends, which it does reasonably well, thanks to two endings that are up for interpretation. It's a short stint, but worth looking into if you want to see Philip's story to the end (or ends).

This isn't the most horrifying game I've ever played, but definitely one of the most horrible ones.
I really enjoyed Overture and I just had to play Black Plague after finishing it. And in the beginning I really thought it was better.
But nooo, the developers had to introduce some really annoying things. It's nice that weapons have been removed, the were really unhandy. And not useful at all in this game - not because the new, scarier-than-the-Overture-dogs-looking enemies are dangerous. They're the opposite. They are so fucking slow. Just run past them, 5 seconds later they won't know where you are.
Then there's Clarence. Some kind of demon who possesses you in the beginning and comments everything you do. I guess his comments are supposed to be funny. They're not. They aren't informative, they aren't interesting, but they are really long and distracting, sometimes they even block the controls so you just stay and wait until he stops annoying the shit out of you. He even spoils the most "emotional" moment in the game.
The gameplay, too, becomes annoying. Try solving some riddles while having to run back to a hut every 10-15 seconds so you don't freeze to death. It's not even difficult, it's just extremely tedious. The riddles become really uninspired and in the end I mostly played by a walkthrough because I was done with this piece of crap.
And lo, this ending! Instead of just staying on the "horror" plain, the game suddenly ascends onto a pseudo-metaphysical plain which doesn't fit to the rest at all. I would've liked to laugh, but it was way too stupid.

I'm still going to play Penumbra: Requiem, but only because it's a 100% puzzle game without annoying enemies that just slow you down instead of making things more difficult.

15336088.review:
This is the kind of game you'll have to play with a pair of headphones and no source of light because only then you'll experience its true power. 

The game's overall story is deep, unpredictable and intriguing, making it very interesting, which is a big plus for a horror game. (It even has a few emotional moments!) Even though at the beginning there is a short recap of the events that took place in Overture, I highly recommend playing the first game first in order to have a full understanding of the story. (You can only buy the package containing both games, so why not give it a try?)

Both games are similar in terms of gameplay, but Black Plague improves a lot on about every aspect of the first game, making it more solid. There is no direct way of fighting with the enemies in this installment, so the combat system, which, in my opinion, wasn't that awful, should no longer be a problem for those who complained about it. Another important aspect of the game are puzzles: being the second episode, Black Plague is also filled with intelligent puzzles that require reading (in-game "notes") and thinking, but this time they are just a little easier than those found in Overture.

The graphics may be a little outdated, but there's nothing to worry about because it doesn't break the immersion; they are decent and have successfully created a terrifying atmosphere that will constantly make you scared of the unknown. (For that to work at its full potential, I recommend lowering the gamma a bit, until you can't see anything in places without any source of light.) With its impressive sound design and voice acting (at least for a low-budget game), the developers managed to create their own world filled with few, but believable characters. 

For such a low price, I can recommend the Penumbra games without a doubt! This package is a must-have for every horror enthusiast, as it delivers a frightening experience!

15083062.review:
If you took Portal and turned it into a survival horror narrative you would have the Penumbra series.

Penumbra: Black Plague is the 2nd installment in the series and the best hands down.  The heavy focus on exploration, lack of weapons, brilliant level design, ambient sound and fantastic voice acting make it a well rounded experience that paved the way for games like Outlast and Amnesia: The Dark Descent (this studio actually made that game).

If you love horror you owe it to yourself to play this.  People who assume horror can only be jumpscares will laud FNAF as a 'masterpiece' but that game looks like a sunny day at the park compared to the viscreal scares of Penumbra: Black Plague.

14949358.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague je vo vsetkych smeroch vylepsene priame pokracovanie, v ktorom Vam budu zodpovedane vsetky otazky, nad ktorymi z povodnej hry vyseli otazniky.

Autori sa rozhodli uz uplne vypustit bojovu cast, co hre len prospelo a k slovu sa tak konecne dostava hlavne strach. I ked ziadne zbrane nemate, tak nepriatelia sa tu stale nachadzaju a su ovela desivejsi, ako v pripade Overture a z velkej casti za to moze fakt, ze s nimi nemozete nijako bojovat, len sa pred nimi skryt. Co sposobilo, ze o stiesnenu atmosferu nebude ziadna nudza.

Princip hratelnosti je stale rovnaky, co je samozrejme v poriadku, pretoze co funguje, netreba radikalne menit a v Overture fungovala hratelnost na vybornu. Takze budete opat riesit logicko-fyzikalne hadanky, zbierat uzitocne predmety a postupne sa dozvedat, coze sa to za neprijemnosti vlastne stalo.
Aj ked mi po pribehovej stranke pride druha epizoda lepsia (hlavne vela veci vysvetluje), tak zaroven uz aj o nieco menej zahadnejsia, ako v pripade Overture.

Kazdopadne je Black Plague graficky posobivejsi, hororovejsi a podstatne desivejsi, ako jeho predchodca a rozhodne by ste tuto vybornu hororovu adventuru nemali minut!

14794036.review:
Well, as a second review, I want to make this as positive as can be. Penumbra points out the pefect imperfections of human nature. Dark areas with whispering, slithering, crawling and screaming in the background allows for a more "intimidating" experience. Enemies are fuel for nightmares, conjured up from the fears of fellow humans. The general atmosphere will make your heart pound and make you sweat. The good ol' fashioned jumpscares (how few they are) will last in your memories and well, deep into your dreams. Nightmares* excuse me. 

     Now, the ONE (1) bad thing I had was not game-ruining; a simple lighting error with the shader. A simple fix of course. Lower the shader resolution to medium. Bing, bang you're back in action! If you left in the first place. 

My computer is nothing close to a gaming rig, however, Penumbra runs at above 60fps with hardly (meaning none) any lag ingame, don't be deterred if you're using a less-than-perfect machine. 

     10/10 would rebuy, reinstall and replay it over and over.

14729268.review:
Вы просыпаетесь. Понимаете, что оказываетесь запертыми в разгромленном кабинете. Пытаясь найти ключ вы вдруг прислушиваетесь, и слышите, как вдалеке открывается дверь. Слышаться шаги. Они приближаются. Кто то (или что то) проходит мимо вашей двери, потом вы слышите мольбы неизвестного человека вдалеке, а затем его крики, вперемежку со звуком входящего в плоть лезвия. И крики умолкаются. Шаги удаляются, дверь где то закрывается. И тишина. 

Вам становится страшно, но нужно что то делать, как то искать выход. И вы его находите, но вскоре жалеете об этом. Вы оказываетесь в заброшенной лабораторий, в этих ужасных и мрачных корридорах с мигающими лампами и пятнами крови на стенах. Вы в поисках выхода пробуете открыть любую дверь, но вместо этого натыкаетесь на тех, кто попал под воздействие вируса - ужасных существ с огромными глазами и уродливым телом. Эти существа видят вас и хотят вас убить, а вам остаётся только одно - бежать. И пока вы бежите, вы молите Бога, чтобы побыстрее найти укрытие. Переждав там, вы, скрепя сердце, продолжаете искать выход, ведь большего вам ничего не остаётся. Только найдя выход вы сумеете пережить этот кошмар.

Это игра, где вы будете постоянно находится в постоянном напряжении и страхе. Если вы сумеете побороть его и найти ВЫХОД - вы выживете. А если нет... 

Великолепный хоррор.

10 из 10

14592390.review:
Da der Spielinhalt schon in den höchsten Tönen gelobt wurde, singe ich ganz klar hier mit im Chor!

Jedoch will ich noch Dinge gut heißen, die extrem wichtig sind, aber niemand Bachtung schenkt...

Erstens:
Die Steuerung! 
Sie funktioniert einfach einwandtfrei und die Physik lässt sich problemlos kreativ einsetzen, was allein schon verdammt Spass macht! Auch kann man die Steuerung NACH BELIEBEN modifizieren, was auch mal erwähnt werden muss, weil das (leider) in vielen Spielen fehlt, vor allem als Linkshänder sogar ein Grund das Spiel zur Seite zu legen!

Zweitens:
Die hit Box bzw der Sweetspot: In vielen Spielen kann man Gegenstände in der Umgebung nicht anwählen, interagieren, selbst wenn die Maus genau darauf ist, in Penumbra erscheint sofort die Actionshand wenn man auch nur den Rand des Gegenstandes einen Pixel überschreitet, absolut erwähnenswert und wichtig für ein gutes Spielgefühl!

Drittens:
Einfachheit des Inventars und der Shortcutliste von 1-9: Wenn man zB die Taschenlampe auf einen Slot zieht, kann man sie über diesen benutzen, unnötig, aber flexibel. Es macht auch Spass die gefundenen Gegenstände nach Belieben in den Slots zu ordnen und keiner gegebenen Reihenfolge aufzuerlegen. So kann man seinen EIGENEN Überblick erschaffen und kann so besser nachdenken. Das muss mal erwähnt werden, besonders bei vielen Gegenständen interessant.

Zu guter Letzt:
Wunderschöne Texturen und keine Pixel sichtbar! Sicher, man muss den Grafikstil und das Design mögen weil es speziell ist, aber ich mag es ungemein und ist mir lieber als irgendein steriler normaler Fotorealismus!

Leider sind solche Spiele mit so einem Spielgefühl wie das sehr selten.

14013341.review:
Итак, Penubra: Black Plague - прямое продолжение Penumbra: Overture и вторая игра трилогии Penumbra.
Самое главное, что следует сказать, так это то что ребята из Frictional Games сумели сохранить самый большой плюс первой части - атмосферу. На заднем плане постоянно что-то шуршит, скрепит, стучит. Повсюду разруха и запустение, инфицированный персонал так и норовит сожрать нашего главного героя. В добавок, теперь бы не сможем противостоять им, ведь всё вооружение убрано. Всё, что мы можем, так это сжавшись в уголке, трястись и ждать когда очередное чудовище пройдёт мимо.
Геймплей практические не изменился. Всё так же ходим по заброшенным подземельям Гренландии, всё так же что-то ищем, что-то нажимаем, что-то совмещаем. Но хочу сказать, что Black Plague стала легче, по сравнению с первой частью.
Сюжет продолжает историю первой части.
Как вы помните в конце Overture нашего героя ударили по голове и, наглым образом, куда то утащили. Утащили как оказалось недалеко. Всю игру мы будем бродить по помещениям и комплексам исследовательского комплекса "Мануик", в котором произошла утечка неизвестного вируса, поразившего практически весь персонал, да и самого Филипа в частности. Благодаря вирусу, наш герой получает себе попутчика, в форме разумного вируса - Кевина, который постоянно будет комментировать действия игрока, а также мешать, помогать и конечно же смеяться над "глупой мартышкой" .  По ходу игры мы сможем связаться с одной из выживших - Амабель Свансон и именно к ней так будем спешить всю игру. Основную цель мы так же не забудем, ведь сюда Филип прибыл на поиски давно пропавшего отца, который как раз был работником комплекса "Мануик". По ходу игры мы сможем узнать историю и самого комплекса, с помощью 20 записок, разбросанных по уровням игры.
Penumbra: Black Plague - это вполне достойное продолжение оригинальной игры, которое снова погрузит вас в атмосферу ужаса и одиночества.

by Dedal333, 2015 год

13964158.review:
Real horror is a connection with the audience. It taps into our insecurities, plays on our weaknesses. Real horror is scary because, simply put, it feels real.

This game didn't feel that way. 

Don't misunderstand; I enjoyed it. There's a lot to love about the title, the least of which is the well-integrated physics systems and the "realistic" puzzles. Don't expect doors to start opening just because you found a note somewhere. Not that kind of game, which is a relief. 

But for all that I felt it was more "sci-fi romp" (romp... why do critics and reviewers always use that word?) than "survival horror." At no point during the game did I actually feel that my life was in danger. The conditions are right. The execution is close to right. So what's lacking here?

I think, in the end, the baddies just aren't imposing enough. They're slow, and forgiving to the point that if you run thirty feet away and turn a corner, they give up on you. That and they run simple patrols. Makes this feel more like a stealth mission than a life-threatening escape scenario.

But do play it, because (before the weird end sequence), the writing is just too phenomenal to miss out on. Seriously. It's weird too see a game where the writing outshines everything else for once. It's like they took someone working on a bestseller and said "hey, forget the book. Come write journal entries for our game." Pretty astounding, really.

3.8/5 for me.

13837735.review:
In my opinion, The Black Plague was even better than the original, Overture. My only problems, though, stemmed from the fact that numerous puzzles were just too hard and frustrating for me. Namely, the dreaded three or four final levels. I basically had to keep a pair of walkthroughs open in the Steam overlay so I could finally finish the game. People who are far smarter than me wouldn't have as much trouble as I did.
Other than that, yes, it's a good game. The plot, the premise, the backstory... everything felt much deeper in here than in Overture. There also seemed to be more substance to the enemies here than in Overture, which were just angry, mangy dogs, annoying spiders and big, scary worms, whcih seemed to have little explanation or relevance to the story. 

This might be a bit of a spoiler...
I noticed that much of what happened here really reminded me of System Shock 2. Hybrids= The Infected. SHODAN/The Many=the thing that is responsible for this whole mess. The Von Braun= The Shelter/Mines. The list goes on.

Anyway, I liked Black Plague a bit more than Overture, though they were both pretty good.

One last note, be careful with the graphics settings, especially screen resolution. I had problems with double images on screen, especially with the player's glowstick. I suspect this stems from the issues with widescreen monitors.
