There isn't much I can say about this as there is not much to say without spoiling it but I highly recommend this if your looking for a pretty good fright or just a good game to immerse yourself in.

13739938.review:
Penumbra Black Plague je FPS survival horror ktorý priamo nadväzuje na prvý diel série Penumbra Overture. 
Hlavný hrdina Philip sa teda na začiatku hry nenachádza v opustených doloch ale v výskumnom komplexe pri čom je odhodlaný zistiť pravdu... Základné techniky hry po Penumbra Overture ostali zachované teda hra obsahuje jednoduché hádanky typu nájsť mincu a odšrobovať s ňou ventilačnú šachtu alebo vyhľadať zapaľovač a zapáliť barel z naftou aby ste sa ohriali a nezamrzli, v istej časti hry. Zmenou je ale aj napríklad to že vy ako postava ste oproti predchádzajúcemu dielu  voči monštrám absolútne bezmocný, teda nemáte ani žiadne vybavenie ako krompáč alebo návnadu z minulého  dielu ktorími sa dalo aspoň minimálne ubrániť voči nepriateľom. 
Aj tak ale hra celkovo nie je nejakým spôsobom ťažká príbeh, nie je moc dlhý ale hra ako predstaviteľ žánru horror rozhodne svoj potenciál splňuje napomáha k tomu hlavne perfektná atmosféra z ktorej je vážne cítiť že vy ste ten bezbranný preto sa pred nie zrovna mierumilovnými príšerami buď schovávate alebo utekáte.

Po technickej stránke hra funguje na HPL engine ktorý je po stránke fyziky veľmi dobrý na druhú stranu grafická stránka tejto hry nie je moc dobrá. Čo je však veľmy dobréje zvuk hry ktorý len dopĺňa
skvelú atmosféru.
Hardwarové požiadavky sú teda celkom nízke takže to spojazdníte aj na menejvýkonejších počítačoch.
Bohužiaľ narazil som aj na pár chýb ktoré sa týkali väčšinou umelej inteligencie po ktorých my počase prišli tie horrorové pasáže až vtipné, pretože ak môžete okolo toho strašidelného monštra len tak prejsť a nič sa nestane dokonca ešte začne chodiť tupo do steny je to na pobavenie. Celkovo sa toto však nestávalo často a väčšinou všetko fungovalo ako má.

Záver je taký že táto hra vás vystraší celkom poctivo a je to aj zábavné, hádanky nie sú moc ťažké a vďaka HPL engine si to zahrajte aj na starších zostavách. Umelá inteligencia je priemerná ale level design spoločne s zvukovými efektmi sú perfektné.
Osobne som hru prešiel raz ale myslím že sa ku nej vrátim minimálne raz.

Celkové hodnotenie je: 8,5/10

13678114.review: Mechanically, Black Plague improves on Overture by removing combat, making escape and evasion the only tactics when confronted with enemies. This doesn't mean they are any more difficult to deal with, however. They may look substantially more imposing than the first game's dogs, but they behave almost identically, making them very easy to exploit. The other elements of the game are simply more of the same, though that isn't a bad thing. Storywise, Black Plague leaves behind the  mines of Overture and throws the player into decrepit laboratories with the added atmospheric touch of significantly more sinisterly splattered blood and ominous corpses. More characters are introduced early on, though while this improves the player engagement this time around, one of them is very talkative and voiced in a manner that is highly incongruous with the setting. Think "The Darkness". The tone is a horrible mismatch, and the atmosphere suffers as a result.

13237456.review:
Black Plague-вершина прогресса серии Penumbra. Все сбалансировано идеально-похождения по станции "Мануик",решение головоломок,прятки с монстрами,чтение записок.Сюжет очень хорош,создатели вдохновлялись фильмом "Нечто" и 
творчеством Говарда Лавкрафта.
У главгероя Филлипа отобрали оружие,убрали убогих врагов из первой части,также как и вонючие пустые коридоры. Врагов теперь намного меньше,но в интеллекте они,конечно,не прибавили.
Также не может не радовать такой персонаж,как Кевин (в оригинале Кларенс,а Кевин-измышление локализаторов).Кевин поселился у главгероя в башке,и всю игру радует вас своими саркастичными комментариями.Игра очень коротка,а так как ,в отличие от первой части,все ненужные коридоры выпилили,каждый игровой момент насыщен чем то интересным. Появились,в отличие,опять же,от Overture,интересные геймплейные стиуации,как то:ситуация на псарне,когда приходится передвигаться вместе со светом(в противном случае тварь,бывшая раньше главным смотрителем станции,сожрет вас),также впечатляют побегушки от мутантов в самом финале,когда Кевин мучает тебя жестким трипом,и ты почти не видишь,куда бежишь.
2 часть,по моему,не является хоррором,скорее уж адвенчурой с элементами стелса.Но купив ее,вы,вполне возможно,испугаетесь неоднократно в процессе прохождения.
В общем,подытожив,Requiem  надо брать не раздумывая,коль скоро уж вам нравятся игры с неплохим сюжетом.

А теперь про 3 часть,едва тянущую на дополнение,Requiem.
Описать можно одним словом-ужасно. Оно и неудивительно-на волне успеха Black Plague разработчикам пришлось делать Requiem менее чем за год.В итоге вышел бессвязный,бессюжетный набор головоломок.
Разрабы намутили кучу всего,однако,понять сюжетный замысел все же можно. Но,если убрать из игры все головоломки и попрыгушки с ящиками,сюжета наберется минут на 5!Да ивообще, я не большой фанат игр,в которых,кроме головоломок,ничего нет. Тем более ,что здесь есть абсолютно упоротые задачки,на решение которых может уйти часа 2 (потому что,мать вашу,нужный для прохождения предмет провалился в текстуры!)Пройдя эту игру один раз (на диске брал),и купив в стиме,второй раз я cтрадать не буду.

Лучше уж поиграйте в мод к Amnesia:the dark descent,под азванием Penumbra:necrologue.Идейный продолжатель Black plague,сильная сюжетная часть,интересный геймплей,в общем,именно такой должна быть 3 Penumbra (разрабы даже советовались с Frictional games!)
А Requiem можете пройти,но только ради того,чтобы увидеть концовки.

13103507.review:
В данном обзоре будет описана игра Penumbra: Black Plague и расширение Penumbra Requiem !

Penumbra Black Plague (Пенумбра Черная чума) - вторая глава  о темных и загадочных приключениях Филиппа, под разработкой Frictional Games и издательством Paradox Interactive. Продолжается история, начатая в Penumbra Overture. В отличии от своего предшественника, Black Plague происходит в лабораториях уровнями ниже места в первой Пенумбре. Персонаж продолжает поиски своего отца и сталкивается с еще более трудными вопросами, на которые необходимо найти ответы. В игре появился новый вид противников, еще более опаснее и разумнее чем никогда. Система инвертаря осталась той же, но у героя забрали все оружие. Теперь вступать в стычки с монстрами смертельно опасно. Кроме этого добавлены артефакты, которые нужно собирать по прохождении игры, дающие доступ к определенным бонусам. Игровой процесс обновлен различными ловушками,тупиками и головоломками. Все это под прекрасный саундтрек, наиболее подходящий по атмосфере. Сюжетные повороты делают геймплей более шокирующим. Вы готовы разгадать все тайны этого места и узнать правду?
Оценка 10/10

Penumbra Requiem - третья и заключительная глава в этой мрачной истории. Геймплей претерпел очень значительные изменения, а именно:
1. Фонарик стал бесконечным, а батарейки искать не требуется.
2. Напрочь отсутствуют все монстры (по сюжету второй части станет понятно,почему).
3. Множественные отсылки на первую Пенумбру.
4. Теперь подбирая любую вещь автоматически происходит сохранение
5. Возвращение старого героя с еще более темным прошлым
6. Увеличено количесто квестов
7. Наличие двух концовок, выбор за вами
Учитывая отсутствие монстров, можно сказать, что атмосфера страха практически исчезла, лишь нагнетение обстановкой и локациями могут заставить немного пощекотать нервишки
Оценка 7/10 

Рекомендую всем купить и сыграть в эту трилогию. Она прекрасна, интересна и очень загадочна !

Одна из лучших хоррор-игр, которые я знаю.
Сначала резюме, потом длиннопост:
[h1]Хорошо:[/h1]
[list]
[*]атмосфера
[*]графика
[*]физика
[*]сюжет
[*]знатные головоломки
[/list]

[h1]Плохо:[/h1]
[list]

[*]вылет при попытке выставить разрешение выше 1280x1024
[/list]

[h1]Мысли по поводу:[/h1]

Первое, что бросается в глаза и придаёт немалую долю страха - наш герой полностью безоружен. Это вам не Dead Space какой-нибудь, где почти все по-идее-безопасные достижения инженерной мысли будущего можно использовать для размазывания чудищ по стенам. Хочешь жить - умей вертеться (в контексте Penumbra - бегать, прятаться, думать, думать, снова думать, снова бегать).

Думать - ключевое слово на протяжении всей игры, и это реально сложно делать, когда тебе приходится быстро бегать от недоброжелательно настроенных белых гуманоидов. Однако чтобы продвинуться дальше, головоломки приходится решать очень непростые - интерактивные предметы не подсвечиваются, что смог сдвинуть с места - то и используй:) Этот принцип - единственное, что как-то позволяет решать головоломки. Добавили бы мусора и дезинформации - был бы аццкий ад.

При этом головоломки отлично вписаны в общую канву сюжета и атмосферы. История не кажется высосанной из пальца, и вот уж действительно, чем дальше в лес - тем больше дров. Поплыли мы совать нос в тёмное прошлое отца, которого никогда не знали - приплыли... Фиг пойми куда приплыли, но там жутко. Попробуйте сами - и всё станет ясно.

В общем, это отличный хоррор, в который надо играть в наушниках, ночью, одному, и понемногу. Чтобы не трепать нервы слишком сильно:)

12405223.review:
This is an atmospheric first person survival horror game at its best. Combat is there, but almost completely obsolete against your enemies. You are much better off using stealth and tactics. *Thinking*. Using the environment to your advantage. This is a real horror simulator where you are the victim, the target. You are not a survivor, you are not a well-armed super-soldier blasting his way through zombies, parasitic creatures, mutants, and the hordes of hell. 

Before I go ranting about how to play this game and how it is so different from the common horror shooters that are actually *fun to play* and inevitably drive you away from a well-spent ten bucks on this game...

You're locked inside a building where nobody is your friend and all your enemies have bigger d*cks than you. In fact, they're so proud of their d*cks they're willing to display them, with a facial expression that says "look at my big dick while feeling so inferior, saddened in your depression that even the big f*cking worm prefers me to you. That if any girl were around, she would see that your dick was so inferior to mine."

Of course, you won't be looking at their face or facial expression, because you will be so distracted by the sheer, immesne size of their d*ck. Even when they try to kill you, you will not be able to help but look at the big, red, erect thing between their legs. You'll find yourself running away from them, maybe turning back to catch a few glances... and then finding yourself going back to get another good look. 

You also run into these strange objects that Philip (Yes, your protagonist's name is Philip...) feels the need to masturbate with. He even goes out to say “Every time, it’s harder to pull out. Every time, I feel more of myself inside.” at least *one* time in the game. I must say that it's quite an experience. I feel more of myself rushing out too... I don't want to pull out. I want to keep going. Now, back to talking about the game:

This is not FEAR. Instead of being r*ped (because steam doesn't like the R word) by an 8 year old girl and killing ghosts in slow-motion, you will feel utterly helpless as large, gray skinned men beat you to a bloody pulp and get their bloody pulp inside you. You won't care, because you'll still be distracted by their d*ck.

There's a story, somewhere, along with schizophrenia and some rather tense moments. However, it would be better without the schizophrenia and split personalities, which get really damned annoying at times and totally fuck the entire sense of terror and fear. Imagine getting off really hard and having your uncle walk right in and say "Oh yeah, I used to do that all the time." Not only does it kill the moment, but you want to stop and never do it again. Think of your dead great grandmother watching you masturbate and laughing at how you're doing it so "wrong". It really kills you.

Sorry, back to the game. Well, no, I've just about wrapped it up and concluded it. You'll have some "half-life" type puzzles involving physics (Placing blocks on a lever is the extent...) and some resident evil style puzzles involving pushing boxes around. That's about it. You might find the combat system to be fun if you're really bored. You can throw boxes at enemies to try and kill them (Boxing Match). This will allow you to inspect their large d*cks more closely.

12089973.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague might not have the best graphics, but it makes up for it with gameplay. Penumbra was developed by the same company that made Amnesia, and has many of the same aspects. It has enemies that roam around randomly, and puzzles that make you think WHILE being hunted down. 

In my opinion, the story for Black Plague is much more interesting than Amnesia's. The characters have amazing personalities (Clarence), and you will grow attached to them throughout the game. Some puzzles are unnecessarily hard, but I am proud to say I beat it without using a walkthrough.

If you enjoyed Amnesia: The Dark Descent, Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs, or Outlast, Definitely try this game.

11952482.review:
Продолжение злоключений Филиппа Лафрекса где-то в Гренландии. 

Действия в [b]Black Plague[/b] начинается сразу после событий [b]Overture[/b] и переносятся из шахт с паучьими лазами в просторные корридоры исследовательского комплекса, возведённого над этими самыми шахтами. Ещё более жуткая атмосфера достигается за счет "инфицированных" и ещё большей беспомощности персонажа перед опасностями. Теперь единственный способ выжить - убегать. По качеству головоломки не уступают приквелу, здесь они вне всяких похвал - задачи не просты, но в тоже время логичны. Игра не бездушна и вызывает прямо таки чувства от утраты, тех персонажей, которые помогают главгерою, но неминуемо погибают. 

А штука, которая идёт в комплекте под названием [b]"Requiem"[/b] просто пшик, который даже обозревать не хочется. Очень был расстроен, когда проходил эти почти бессвязные миссии. Абсолютный сюрреализм происходящего, едва заметная связь с предыдущими эпизодами игры и ощущение, что персонаж в безопасности, а всех монстров съели. Очень удручает. Проходить строго тем, кто прошел первые два эпизода игры и желает увидеть, чем всё это в итоге закончилось. Хотя конец никого не удивит.

[b]Black Plague[/b] могла бы стать "жемчужиной" серии за счет мрачного исследовательского комплекса и забавного Кевина в голове персонажа, но лично мне сюжет показался слит: высший разум, иллюминаты, околофилософия. В любом случае, какое-то объяснение происходящему разработчикам нужно было дать игроку и, к сожалению, это не то, что я ожидал увидеть. Но это не делает игру хуже. Это по прежнему достойный представитель жанра.

The sequel to Overture, Black Plague further tells the story of Philip which eventually comes to an end. In fact, it turns out, this is not the final episode (as Requiem includes further chapters) but for me it seemed like the final chapter of his adventure.

The story now continues and tells us much, much more. Running and hiding is even more frequent and from this episode we can clearly see the couple of places that inspired Frictional Games to make Amnesia. The game is also somewhat longer.

Since this is an essential part of a great survival horror trilogy, look for discount on the trilogy pack (if there's any) so that all episodes can be purchased at once. The story and gameplay are both well worth the ride!

11254397.review:
To start: I used to add a header to every one of these reviews, but it oftentimes made the review too long to submit, so I've left it on my Backloggery page. Also, since this game comes with Penumbra: Requiem, I'll talk about that game in this review as well.

Gameplay (Black Plague): Truth be told, you should probably refer back to the Overture review if you wanna know about the mechanics of the game. Since this is a sorta episodic game, I won't go into too much detail again about the mechanics. Just know that they remain largely unchanged. What has changed - and definitely for the better - is the atmosphere. Oh man, it's a lot better this time around. Again, it's not quite Dark Descent territory, but it's pretty dang good. The extra enemy variety helps out a lot as well. Another thing that has changed for the better is the puzzle design. They do require a bit more thought than the average puzzle in Overture would, but the puzzles still make logical sense and are less prone to breaking. All in all, it's the same from Overture but a lot better. 8/10.

Gameplay (Requiem): If ya like puzzles and not being scared... go play Portal 2 or something. Seriously; I don't even know why this became a thing. This game is mostly puzzles with some platforming here and there, but there's no monsters. There's no atmosphere. It's pretty much Myst if you've turned the Gamma down to 0.1 or something. That's not a bad thing, though; a lot of the puzzles in this game are quite good. It's just not a Penumbra game. Also, the atmosphere... they're just taking the piss at this point. There's a Donkey Kong parody in there. No, I'm not joking. There's even chippy music. As if the game wasn't far removed enough from the Penumbra atmosphere. Again though, the puzzles are pretty good. It's just not a Penumbra game. 6/10.

Story (Black Plague): A lot tighter of a story than Overture's. Clarence is a pretty neat and genuinely terrifying character/concept. Likewise, there's actually a couple of pretty heavy moments toward the end (for those who know what I'm talking about, pun well intended). Everything's pretty well explained and the ending wraps things up quite well. No need for a sequel. 8/10.

Story (Requiem): ...and then this thing happened. Again, just... why? The story doesn't even take itself seriously. For anybody who bought Requiem from retail; I'm sorry. I apologize on behalf of Frictional (not affiliated). The characters are just silly, the premise doesn't make any dosh garn sense, the payoff is underwhelming, and it's just generally a mess. At least Dark Descent redeemed them. 3/10.

Graphics (Black Plague): Again, a lot more of the same but better. Enemy design is the biggest standout as far as graphics goes. As for the technical side, same engine; same reliability. 4/5.

Graphics (Requiem): None of the enemy design from Black Plague. At least areas are pretty varied, even if the framing device doesn't work. Again, for the technical side of the things, it's the same as Black Plague. 3/5.

Sound (Black Plague): I'd say it's about the same as Overture's, which is to say very good. Enemies sound a lot more terrifying now, so that's a plus. Clarence sounds proper mental this time as opposed to cartoonishly mental. Good stuff. 5/5.

Sound (Requiem): Way too try-hard. So much attempted atmosphere for so little worth fretting over. It gets kinda ridiculous, honestly. Ah well; it's not like anything else in the game was cohesive. 2/5.

Overall scores for Black Plague are 8/8/4/5; cumulative score of 8.3/10. Good stuff.

Overall scores for Requiem are: 6/3/3/2; 4.7/10. Not good stuff.

A série Penumbra é uma experiência sensacional para quem gosta de jogos de terror.
Overture tem um combate esquisito e inimigos que só apresentam ameaça nas primeiras vezes. Requiem são vários puzzles (alguns entediantes) com uma atmosfera de suspense até boa, mas acréscimo praticamente nulo à história.

Já Black Plague é o ápice da série, uma verdadeira obra-prima do terror, onde a história fica ainda mais intrigante do que já era em Overture, mas sem combate, o que deixa o fator medo/pânico no nível em que já deveria estar desde o começo. Sempre com uma atmosfera pesada, boa trilha sonora, diálogos (monólogos?) bem interpretados, puzzles interessantes e um enredo cheio de surpresas, esse jogo é um prato cheio para fãs do estilo. Podem comê-lo.

11172843.review:
Black Plague was a good survival horror game that you might not want to play at 1 am while alone in the dark.  The plot really advances the story of Penumbra Overture and is also emotionally captivating.  I really enjoyed this one, if being scared for 11 hours can really count as an enjoyable experience.

I do not, however, recommend Requiem.  The best I can liken it to is if George Romero made the zombie horror movies Night of the Living Dead, Dawn of the Dead, but then made Day of the Dead a musical romance about vampires.  Let me be perfectly clear, Requiem is not a survival horror, it is a puzzle game, and not even genuinely creepy.  Half the time it isn't even clear what you're supposed to be doing with the puzzles, you just kind of see there is something you can do and then do it, and everything seems to work out.  Without giving anything away, it felt like an afterthought and I don't think it added anything to the story.  If anything, it was an anti-climactic buzzkill with a convoluted story that did nothing to advance the series.

Unless you like platform jumping and puzzles for the sake of puzzles that have (mostly) no discernable purpose, stop at the end of Black Plague and use your imagination and decide what you want to happen from there.  Since Black Plague is 2/3 of this package I still recommend it, even if my review was very critical of Requiem.

Tämä on niistä yksistä peleistä joilla on sydämessäni erikoinen paikka - Ensipelaamiseni jälkeen rakastuin Penumbran-maailmaan, myös huomattavasti yli Amnesian ja toivonkin Frictional Gamesin tekevän vielä jatkoa tälle pelisarjalle.

Black Plague jatkaa suoraan siitä mihin Overture loppui - Aikaisempaa (Näistä kahdesta helposti heikompaa) osaa ei kuitenkaan ole täysin pakollista pelata saadakseen tarinasta kiinni sillä alussa käydään lävitse nopeasti aikaisemmat tapahtumat.

Heti alusta on selvää että Black Plagueta on paranneltu huomattavasti edeltäjästään; Pelimekaniikka, viholliset, musiikki ja äänitehosteet sekä ylipäätänsä miljöö sekä tunnelma - Vihollisia on edelleen hyvin vähää laatua mutta henk.koht. koen enemmän pakokauhun hetkiä paettessani humanoidia alien zombieta (Mitälie.) kuin mutanttikoiraa (Tämä on ongelmani monien kauhupelien kohdalla, miksi aina zombiekoiria?)

Myös kiehtova tarina syvenee ja saa uusia käänteitä.
Puzzlet ovat edelleen haastavia mutta pienellä ajattelulla selvitettäviä.
Tekoäly ei ole huonointa mitä olen nähnyt mutta vihollisia on silti välillä todella helppo harhauttaa - Sankarimme Philip myös juoksee todella lujaa joten huomasin itsekkin vain hiihtäväni muutamissa tilanteissa käytävien läpi, tietäen että niiden päässä oleva ovi vie turvaan.

Peli loppui mielestäni hienoiseen cliffhangeriin ja tarjoilee eväät pelisarjan kolmannelle osalle, joskus tulevaisuudessa (Frictional Games, tehkää se.)

Penumbra Requiemia eli Penumbra Puzzle Kokoelmaa ei tietenkään lasketa episodi kolmoseksi - Joka sen lukemani perusteella piti olla mutta ei saatu koskaan valmiiksi ja myytiin vain lisäosana Black Plaguelle, ns. closure tarinalle ja vastauksia joihinkin kysymyksiin.

Perinteisellä arvosteluasteikolla 8/10 - Huomattava parannus esiosastaan ja loistava lisäys kenen tahansa selviytymiskauhu peleistä tykkäävän kokoelmaan.

С этой игрой связано много приятных воспоминаний (познакомился я с ней в далёком 2008 году). После выпуска первой части “Penumbra: Overture” Frictional Games сделали огромный шаг вперёд (разнообразили локации; добавили больше предметов, с которыми можно взаимодействовать и новых, не плохо озвученных героев). Самыми важными особенностями Пенумбры, как и в предыдущей части, являются звук; музыка и освещение. Игра очень атмосферная и напоминает разные фильмы ужасов ("Нечто" Джона Карпентера; "Пандорум" и тд). Подача истории, как и сюжетные повороты на высоте (никогда не знаешь, что может произойти). Разочаровывает только то, что главный герой совсем не разговаривает (а хотелось бы), так, например, в “Call of Cthulchu: Dark corners of the earth”, Джек Уолтерс постоянно бормотал себе под нос, какие-нибудь фразочки, которые придавали игре ещё больше мрачности (ведь он побывал в психушке). Penumbra пропитана любовью к Говарду Филлипсу Лавкрафту, а я очень сильно уважаю мастера мистической прозы, поэтому: 

10/10

10281757.review:
I think that people ignore this game and give all of their praise to Amnesia is CRIMINAL... Okay, it's not, but it's really annoying. Sure, Amnesia may have been a more polished experience (albeit with a convoluted story), but Black Plague introduced literally every noteworthy game mechanic that people think Amnesia invented. I also liked the story and characters better. I can't think of any character in Amnesia that outdoes Clarence, and while story isn't as Lovecraftian or whatever, it at least made sense to me.

Don't get me wrong; I like both games, but I'll always give the edge to Black Plague because of its -actual- originality, as well as its more modern setting, which appeals to me more on a personal level. You don't need to have played Overture, which is the Penumbra game that came before, and that's good, because Black Plague is better by leaps and bounds. Some of the physics puzzles may get you stuck, but it's nothing a walkthrough won't help. If you liked Amnesia at all, then you'd at least like Black Plague.

10191037.review:
[i] "Every time, it’s harder to pull out. Every time, I feel more of myself inside.” [/i]

Penumbra: Black Plague is the second of three episodes in the Penumbra series. While continuing the compelling storyline from the first instalment it also improves the characterization of the protagonist. Furthermore, the excellent music background contributes to the immersive atmosphere of the game. The puzzles are challenging and enjoyable, without being illogical or forced. 

Without the awkward combat system of the prequel, your only means of defense are hiding, running or using the environment to your advantage, leaving you with a sense of helplessness on your journey of self-discovery. 

[i] Trivia: [/i]

Penumbra: Requiem is the third and last episode in the Penumbra series. Originally intended to be a trilogy the series was reduced to two episodes due to unidentified problems with the previous publisher, Lexicon Entertainment. In the end, the third instalment came in form of an expansion pack in order to tie up loose ends and put the focus more on the puzzles.

[i] Amusing quotes: [/i]

[i] “Is the emergency figurative or literal? A figurative emergency might, for example, involve an undersupply of coffee to the vending machines. A literal emergency, on the other hand, might involve flesh eating monsters rampaging about the facility.” [/i]

[i] “So… you are running around with a human body part in your backpack, and I am supposed to be the bad guy?” [/i]

[i] Achievements: [/i]

The game has no Steam achievements.

9931391.review:
My recommendation: Buy it.

Pros and Cons:

+ Great, creepy atmosphere
+ Interesting puzzles
+ Good story

- Small variety of enemies
- Simple AI

To avoid any spoilers, I'll just say that the game starts right where the Penumbra: Overture ended. You still play as Philip, in his search for his father and the truth behind the mysterious events in the Greenland mine.
While the game preserves most of the features from the first episode - like exploration, puzzle solving and stealth - the combat system has been completely removed. Personally, I think that the lack of ability to fight back makes the game a lot more tense, especially because of the very creepy enemy design.
However, enemy variety is still quite poor, but for one there is a lot less of them than in the first episode, and I've never felt that enemies were there just for the sake of it.

The plot really develops in this episode, it's well written and interesting. There is a lot more interaction with characters, and some of them may even "grow" on you (pun intended), and the whole setting is much more twisted than it was in its predecessor.
Voice acting and dialogues are also much better, while sound assets, musical score and graphical capabilities remain pretty much on par with Overture. There is also a lot more variety in level design and in the overall environments. While it's not that important, it's worth mentioning that the AI is still fairly simple, and that it's not particularly difficult to lose pursuing enemies.

In general, it's a great sequel, especially in it's story. While it's scarier than Overture, it doesn't rely on jump scares, but on it's fantastic atmosphere. Definitely play it if you like horror games, but make sure to play Overture first for the complete experience.

Early on, the game teaches you that barricading doors with heavy objects doesn't work as the basic enemy simply flings the door open, but later, you have to do just that. 9754015.review:
WARNING: SPOILERS!!

How do I start? Penumbra Black Plague is an EXCELLENT game. Frictional Games have really defined themselves as experts in the horror genre. The first game, Overture, was good but it lacked the horror we experience in Black Plague. In Overature, you can fight your enemies with various tools you find throughout the environment. While this was a good idea in itself, the physics based movement/interaction coupled with combat made for an incredibly clunky control scheme. However, in Black Plague, you cannot fight your enemies. You can either run and hide, or die.

Most people know Frictional Games for their work on Amnesia: The Dark Descent. People believe that this title set the standard for horror games. But to really see what horror is like, you need to go back to Amnesia's roots, which all started with The Penumbra Series. Black Plague does more than just scare you. It makes you question reality. It makes you wonder what really is possible, and what is just the making of a nightmare. 

You start as a Philip, a dangerously deranged man who has just been to hell and back during the first game in the series, Overture. You wake up in an a prison cell, your mind completly fragmented, with no recollection of how you got to where you are. You have to put the pieces back together through notes, puzzles, and exploration. As you make your way through the abandoned facility, you realize that your shattered memory is not the only thing you need to worry about. There is something much more terrifying thats lurkes the hallways. As you duck and dodge through a multidude of enemies, you must figure out the reason for the madness that is happening all around you. 

As you uncoover more secrets and start getting your memory back, you realize that you can no longer simply escape. You discover a sinister plague, something that has taken control of not only everyone around you, but yourself as well. You must find a way to stop it from spreading to the outside world. You must destroy it! Stricken with insanity, voices insulting and deterring you with every step, as well as the many grotesque creatures that patrol each corridor all add up to a horror game that is a cut above all the others. 

9/10 - A near perfect horror experience

You will thoroughly enjoy the horror that this title has to offer! (FOR BEST EXPERIENCE, PLAY ALONE, WITH YOUR LIGHTS OFF, AND WITH HEADPHONES.)

9599652.review:
This Linux port is not OK. I gave it a try for 40min, but in the end I gave up. It's the experience that turned me away.

First I started it to see if my Intel card can take it. Surprinsingly, it appeared to work very well in 1280x1024 (good framerate for this type of game, decent texture quality). I had to configure it from using Pulse Audio to ALSA, but that's OK. A lot of applications don't get the Pulse Audio integration right. Then I grabbed a coffee and prepared to go through this game from A to Z. I wanted to experience all its features.

The first hickup: multiple monitors. I have a second monitor connected to my laptop. The xrandr/xcb support for this is working perfectly (all applications [thus far] supporting multiple monitors have no issues). But this game simply doesn't get it right. The list of resolutions is weird (I don't know where it gets those), I can't predict on which screen it will start and if I increase the resolution past 1280x1024, it will use both monitors in one large canvas with the game centered. It's unusable. Thus, I'm stuck with a low(ish) resolution.

The game tries to start in fullscreen mode, but today it started doing a decoration-less window mode. Very unusual. There does not seem to be a truly _windowed_ mode, which most Linux users will prefer specifically because fullscreen with X is a very complicated affair.

The next hiccup: the sound. There's a constant "click", as if the game constantly misses the deadlines when feeding the audio sink.

The next hiccup: CPU usage. Even though I'm in the main menu, the application consumes 100% of my CPU time. I appears to be constanly rendering something, event though I can't see anything noticeable changing. But maybe my driver is not so stellar. Actually, I'm sure it's not. When switching from X to the terminal, the CPU usage drops to ~6%.

The game itself: I started with the tutorial. There's a step where I have to put a box into a coffin. Took me four tries to do that, because the box dissapears all of sudden. Eventually I managed to drop it in the coffin, but it made me woder if there was any QA involved in making this port.

At this point I was pretty bummed and I was ready to do something else, but I kept doing the tutorial until my system rebooted (my laptop's fans didn't keep up with the generated heat; but that's an unrelated hardware issue I have). Hence: this review.

All in all, the game looks very interesting and _maybe_ I'll try it again later, but it's a pitty that I had to step into all these issues which remind me of the Xfree86/artsd era. Maybe it works better on a desktop. Who knows,

9579208.review:
Penumbra: Black Plague is quite simply, a continuation of Penumbra: Overture. It might as well be considered one single game. The engine seems to be the same used in the first game, and most mechanics are identical. The atmosphere continues to be dark and creepy, with the addition of some new surprises that surface throughout. Everything is basically the same, with only the plot and storyline developing further. The one major improvement in comparison to Overture is the amount of thrills found in this iteration. There seems to be more action and more atmosphere overall, which makes the game more enjoyable, more creepy and a bit more scary. The story progression isn't as interesting or original as in the first game, but at least it has much more detail and much more depth. The voice acting also continues its high quality performances. Loading times are atrocious and much longer than in the first game, which tests patience. Some of the puzzles included in this game aren't as logical as in the first. The unintuitive puzzles are more complicated and mostly involve trial and error during a particular segment of the adventure. There are also more absurdly hidden items and mechanisms, which makes this game much more difficult in terms of its playability as an adventure game. There is also more interaction between the player and other characters in the story, which quickly dissolves the feeling of being a solitary person in a creepy and scary locale. The developers decided to get rid of the melee combat instances completely (found in the first game), which I agree is for the best and makes the game more tense and more fluid. There are way too many interruptions for plot development voice acting. Without ruining the experience with spoilers, I will say that these voice acting pauses occur almost at any given time, without a focus on storyline turning points. They can get a bit distracting at times. Not having the ability to engage your enemies in melee combat makes the game so much more tense and exciting. The ending is very good and adds to the story rather well. Penumbra: Black Plague is better than Penumbra: Overture in every way, as it corrected some of the developers' mistakes and made the gaming experience more enjoyable as a whole. This is clearly the best adventure game I have ever played; totally exceeding Penumbra: Overture. Once again, the game runs a little bit short, but I suppose it is of adequate length after all, since it is an adventure game with lots of theme and mood. I am now looking forward to the third part in the series.

Penumbra: Black Plague is good.

9578231.review:
Easily the best game of the Penumbra series. The movement is pretty smooth, the puzzles are a good challenge, it scares you while pacing itself and the story is good. The game is a tad bit buggy sometimes, but glitches don't occur often, so it's negligible. Unlike Overture's stupid combat system, there are no means of self defense. This, paired with the humming of machines and flourescent lights and other ambient noises makes the environment very creepy. A major flaw of this game is the budget: it's not too long and isn't very pretty looking. But who the hell cares? I think that might be the reason this game got such a low metacritic rating. But if you judged it on how scary it is, take the the total points of the Dead Space Series, divide by three, then add 10 and that's the score this game deserves. 

Short Review: Scary, fun/10, definitely worth playing.

9506393.review:
Great follow up to the 1st part (Overture).  The puzzles you need to solve (again, like in the 1st part, they are evnvironmental for the most part) are substantially more challenging and there is  essentially  no combat in this one, rather, you need to truly make use of stealth this time around if you want to survive.  

As for the umbilical gibbering manchildren things running around, I just about sh*t myself the first time I saw one (you'll know when the 1st sighting is about to occur as the character you are states that you need to hide, but I wasn't quite expecting what came walking through the door next).

The lab/research facility a majority of this entry takes place in is definitely spooktacular and the graphics and sound are stll in top form (well, maybe not the graphics but the sound for sure).

All in all this was a fun adventure and I can't wait to play the final part (Requiem).

LATER (3/17/14 @ 6:30 PM EST):

Well, I finally played + completed the final part (Requiem) and I have to say it was...interesting.  It kinda, sorta gave me the impression that it didn't quite belong in the Penumbra series, like it was a standalone game based, in part, on the 1st two games (Overture and Black Plague), but it was still a good game.  

The puzzles were even more complex this time around and entirely environmental in nature; so much so that it should have been called Penumbra: Requiem for a Puzzle Solver.  Also, (this is a pseudo SPOILER if you read on and may throw some off from wanting to play the game at all knowing what Overture and Black Plague had to offer) there were no creatures at all save for a vague shadowy form under the water in the sewer area.

Overall, this was probably my least favorite of the 3 parts in this series, but it was still fun and if you find yourself to be a hardcore Penumbra fan after the 1st two parts, then you should definitely give this one a go too!

9417681.review:
Continuación de "Penumbra Overture" en el que nos sumergiremos en un oscuro lugar donde pasan cosas realmente muy chungas. Se trata, como el juego anterior, de una aventura en primera persona en donde podemos espicharla. Cuando intuyas que se acerca un bicho raro, no busques armas porque no las hay, escóndete o huye.
La atmósfera es exquisita y el desarrollo del juego también, y si lo que te mola es pasar miedo más allá de ver la programación de Telecinco, prueba este juego.
La historia tiene un papel bastante importante, y se nos irá dosificando adecuadamente mediante notas a lo largo del juego. Presta mucha atención a los sonidos ("¿eso eran pisadas? ¿un grito? ¿un cuesco de mi mujer?") porque será lo que te salve la vida.
La luz escasea, así que vamos armados con una linterna, pero úsala con cuidado porque como ya sabemos los que hemos jugado a "Penumbra Overture", se gasta.
Estás ante un juego imprescindible porque, ¡joder!, es un juegazo y porque es fácil encontrarlo de vez en cuando de oferta en compañía de toda la saga.

[b]Parece igual que el primero.[/b] Exacto. Es como si hubieran alargado el primero, sólo que otros puzzles en otros escenarios.
[b]Me encanta la historia, pero es que con estos juegos de miedo... me cago encima.[/b] Usa pañales. ¡Ya lo hiciste de bebé!
[b]No he jugado al primero, así que no sé si me liaré mucho con la historia.[/b] Lo primero que te recomiendo es que juegues al primero, pero si por lo que sea no quieres, no importa mucho. Vas a pasar miedo igual.
[b]He leído que junto con este juego va otro llamado "Penumbra Requiem". ¿Qué cojones és?[/b] Pues es un truño de juego que utiliza escenarios parecidos a los de las otras dos entregas pero no sigues una historia. Vas de nivel en nivel en el que cada uno tendrás que resolver un puzzle. No es una aventura, es un maldito juego de puzzle (acciona las palancas en el orden correcto, mueve las cajas de aquí a allá, y chorradas así). Pensaba que sería una última parte de la saga y me sentí estafado, pero bueno, como es gratis, ajo y agua.

9209912.review:
Penumbra Black Plague - сиквел к первой части. Прямое продолжение истории Overture. Игра начинается в том месте, где неожиданно и очень таинственно закончился предыдущий эпизод. При этом, интрига концовки первой части и некоторые тайны, секреты, остаются неизвестными ещё до половины игры. Пожалуй, именно во втором эпизоде сюжет раскрывается полностью. В данной части узнаешь и получаешь ответы на многие вопросы. И складывается уже общая картина об произошедшей катастрофе на станции и роли главного героя в ней. Игра полна различных развилок и неожиданный поворотов. Этим она и цепляет. В каждой последующей важной сценке, всё оборачивается так, как мы, не могли бы и подумать. К тому же, в игре появилось несколько "живых" персонажей, что в свою очередь делает сюжетную линию более разветвлённой. В отличие от первой части, где преимущественно история рассказывалась из листочков и бумажек, в этой всё происходит в реальном времени. В общем, в плане сюжета игра очень прибивала. Отдельная благодарность разработчикам, за непредсказуемость и столь интересное развитие событий.

Геймплей остался практически таким же, за исключение некоторых деталей, а именно. Были убраны практически все виды монстров, присутствовавших в первой части. Но ввели новый вид, который не только кардинально отличался от зомби собак, но и изменил подход к игре и способы её прохождения. Так же убрали всю систему боя и соответственно оружие. Теперь оно присутствует лишь в инвентаре, исключительно как орудие, для решения головоломок. Исходя из этого, от врагов мы можем только убежать, либо спрятаться, в следтсвии чего, главный герой становится очень слабым, уязвимым и беззащитным. Теперь уже приходится внимательно смотреть по сторонам и прислушиватся к подозрительным звукам.

Помимо прекрасного сюжета, игра стала намного более пугающей и страшной. Вот это действительно настоящий хоррор, с гнетущей атмосферой страха и ужаса. В игре много моментов, которые действительно могут испугать, ну или хотя бы заставить вас взволноватся.
Поскольку дейтсвия игры перекочевали с Заброшеной Шахты в Исследовательскую Лабораторию, то карты стали намного красивей и более атмосферными. И если сама схема игры осталось той же(бродим по перекрёсным коридорам и комнатам в поисках нужных предметов, для открытия следующий двери), то разнообразие локаций и головоломок стало на порядок выше и качественней. Во втором эпизоде, упор на различные логические задачки, сделан ещё больше. Практически в каждой следующей комнате, нам попадаются всё новые и новые головоломки. Многие из них сложны и требуют от вас смекалки, заставляя думать немного не стандартно. Но при этом задачки правдоподобны и логичны. Как и в первой части, можно надолго застрять в одном месте, не зная что делать дальше. И когда находишь решение понимаешь, насколько было просто и трудно в тоже время. Ну и конечно же не стоит упускать важные моменты из своих записей, там хранятся не менее ценные подсказки.
Теперь же инвентарь стал более практичным и сбалансированым. Если раньше, мы могли спокойно пройти весь эпизод используя лишь фонарик, то теперь роль зажигательных факелов и неоновой лампы выросли вдвое, втрое.

Средняя графика с текстурами низкого качества, но с грамотной и предельно хорошей работой света. Игра мрачная и тёмная сама по себе, но в игре прекрасное освещение, хорошо сделаны различные визуальные эффекты, наподобие лучей и теней. Улучшена анимация, теперь враги двигаются более плавно, но не очёнь качество самих моделей.
Хороший, мрачный саундтрек и прекрасная озвучка персонажей.
 
[h1] В итоге получаем хоррор головоломку, с интересным сюжетом, атмосферными локациями и своеобразным геймплеем. Прекрасное продолжение серии и истории.

Оценка: 9/10 [/h1]

9163222.review:
This game is plenty entertaining, if a bit frustrating at times and tonally inconsistent thanks to the presence of an annoying "sidekick" character for a good chunk of the game. The atmosphere, while normally good, is at its best when there are no enemies to worry about, since the persistent monster patrols quickly become tiresome. The puzzles are the real star here, and while there are a few stinkers that refer back to the "logic" of early-90s point-and-clickers, they're normally quite tactile and satisfying to complete thanks to liberal use of the physics engine. 

[i]Black Plague[/i], then, is nowhere near as impressive as either Amnesia game when taken as a whole. Still, its flawed story is perhaps the most ambitious that developer Frictional Games has created yet, and its (mostly) enjoyable while it lasts.

9033801.review: 10 dollars for the whole pack..... Really, why haven't you bought it yet? Seriously? So, Overture is a truly well-done game, as the 2nd game Frictional Games, the makers of the Amnesia series and the upcoming Soma, started out with a Penumbra 2006 Tech Demo. (available for free on Frictional Game's site so try it out if you aren't sure about getting it) Then, because of it's rising popularity, they created Penumbra Overture. I really don't want to spoil anything, but it has one of the best atmospheres in gaming. Your father died. You have found a letter left by him, talking about a security deposit. You go to it, and find a note that tells of a faraway place. You go there, and you get caught in a snowstorm. So, you find a buried hatch, open it, and fall into a mine. You have to find a way out. One thing leads to another, and you are stuck in a mental hospital. That, is how they chose to start Penumbra Black Plague. And, I am only halfway through Black Plague. So, 10 DOLLARS FOR 3 FULL GAMES.  and, why get Amnesia for 20 bucks when you can get the first 3 games for 10! Oh, and the games are really good.

9022593.review:
I think I mentioned this in my Overture review but this game blows Amnesia: The Dark Descent away in terms of its plot and actually being a proper horror game. That being said it relies a pretty good amount on you playing the game properly and not just sprinting through it as fast as possible.

Anyone that played Overture (you should play Overture first) will be glad to know that there's less chase sequences in Black Plague. Some of them I couldn't tell if I was actually being chased or not, I wasn't gonna risk it so I hurried anyways. No hordes of spiders chasing you through small tunnels at any rate.

This game is kind of similar to A Machine For Pigs oddly enough in how it handles the plot, I suspect Chinese Room took a lot of inspiration from Black Plague in how they designed AMFP. Though don't get me wrong there's a plethora of ways to die in Black Plague, unlike AMFP which you basically had to try to get something to attack you.

If you enjoyed either of the Amnesia games you'll enjoy Penumbra as well, you just have to keep in mind that it's an older title running on an older engine.

8771685.review:
Penumbra Black Plague is an improvement over its predecessor Penumbra Overture. Instead of fighting random animals, you will encounter mutated humans. Unlike the first game, there is no possibility of combat against them. You are defenseless against them, upping the ante on terror and suspense. The music is still excellent and the controls are solid once you get the hang of them.

This particular package, Penumbra Black Plague Gold Edition also includes the final game of the trilogy, Penumbra Requiem. Unfortunately, it is the worst game in the series -- easily. In this game, I never felt any suspense but mostly frustration because it was loaded with convoluted puzzles (the worst part of the series) and completely lacking any monsters, therefore no sense of being followed (the best and scariest part of the series). I didn't feel a need for wrapping things up with the main character's storyline, which is what Requiem does essentially. Requiem's biggest sin is the fact it centers around the main character completely as opposed to continuing the plot from the previous game, leaving no room for any scary moments whatsoever.

Overall, this game is worth the purchase. Personally I think the series ended well with Black Plague, as there was closure in its conclusion. But if you want to play the whole series for the sake of completion, go for it!

8665483.review:
[h1] OJOCUIDAO: ESTA RECOMENDACIÓN ES DE LA TRILOGÍA DE PENUMBRA, NO SÓLO DEL BLACK PLAGUE [/h1]

Este juego ha caído en el olvido, sea por los años que han pasado desde su lanzamiento o bien por su efímera repercusión. ¿Qué es lo que hace a este título mejor que otros juegos de su género como Outlast o Amnesia? Sencillamente, este survival horror se centra en presentar una muy buena historia con distintas interpretaciones subjetivas acerca de la cordura humana o qué puede haber detrás de eventos sobrenaturales explicados por algo más que un virus, sucesos de ultratumba o alienígenas.

A lo largo de las tres partes, la inseguridad que experimenta el jugador se basa en las dudas que nos repercuten acerca de nuestro entorno: ¿estamos sólos? ¿Todo lo humano con lo que interactuamos indirectamente a lo largo del juego son alucinaciones del personaje o de verdad existe en el universo que presenta el juego? En cierto modo, si os lo habéis pasado os daréis cuenta de que en ninguna de las tres partes hemos llegado a [spoiler]ver un sólo humano vivo, sólo lo hemos llegado a escuchar por walkie talkie, en nuestra mente, en sueños o leído acerca de él [/spoiler].

Pero no todo en esta trilogía se centra en su inquietante historia o en el transcurso de los hechos. Otro punto bastante fuerte de este juego son sus puzzles. Y no son puzzles cualquiera que los creadores han puesto para entretenernos, no. Son puzzles, de los cuales, la mayoría son bastante dificultosos, hay que fijarse bien en cada milímetro de los escenarios y ver más allá de lo que hay ante nuestras narices, en todo el entorno. Sin ir más lejos, hay puzzles en los que se requiere, por ejemplo, encontrar y leer el manual de instrucciones de una vieja maquinaria de un generador, interpretar un código morse para extraer un código... Y muchas cosas también bastante complicadas (lo confieso, padre, he usado guías para pasarme este juego D:).

Los enemigos también son algo crucial en esta saga (salvo en la tercera parte). En el primer juego, aunque los tipos de enemigos son muy simples (arañas, gusanos y perros), nos dan la posibilidad de combatirlos con distintos utensilios (martillos, escobas, picos, dinamita...), aunque siempre hay otras formas de interactuar con el entorno para deshacernos de ellos. En el segundo juego nuestras posibilidades de luchar contra ellos se reducen aún más, ya que habrá que hacer un mayor uso del sigilo y nuestros recursos para luchar se limitan aún más.

Ahora bien, ¿podemos decir que este juego busca causar miedo en el jugador? Quiero pensar que no, y si ese es el objetivo no lo han conseguido. Por supuesto que no es un juego en el que quieren conseguir el susto fácil del jugador. No obstante, la ambientación, todo lo siniestro que vemos, escuchamos o vamos leyendo sí que puede llegar a crear, sobretodo al principio antes de que nos acostumbremos a este ambiente, situaciones de tensión y un poco de agobio. Pero pedazo de nenazas, ¿acaso a vosotros os ha dado miedo el Amnesia? Menuda panda de mariconas.

7.3/10 Ojalá hubiera conocido antes este juego.

8019156.review:
I won't go on and on with this one, but let me just say that before Frictional Games' Amnesia: The Dark Descent became synonymous with fear, they were perfecting their craft with the Penumbra series.

Black Plague is the second of their three-part Penumbra series, but in this man's humble opinion it tops even their most successful of games.

Yes, I said it. It's better than Amnesia. Now before you get to the hate let me just say that I adore Amnesia. It introduced me, as it did so many others, to Frictional Games' work. But once I finished it up I wanted more. I was lucky enough to see this package come up during one of Steam's classic Halloween sales and decided to snag it. For some reason or another, I started Black Plague first, and I couldn't have made a better choice.

This game has it all. From the atmosphere that breathed down my neck, tingling my spine and darkening my thoughts to the gameplay immersing me into the world, this game hits all the right notes. But this one does what I hope Soma (Frictional Games' next title) will do again - make a great story.

I won't spoil anything, but let me just say don't let the atypical setting of a mental asylum fool you. It's much more than that, and giving this game enough of your time to find out why is well worth the investment.

I highly recommend this game.

Puzzles are immensly challenging, roundabout corridors will keep you guessing, and the voice acting (which a lot take for granted) was superb. The entire game took me about five hours to complete (excluding idling at the main menu), and the ending was strangely satisfying. Overall: 9/10, would replay.

7794312.review:
Huh! Unlike the console horror stylings of Overture, Black Plague feels more akin to, say, System Shock. A combatless System Shock! Does that make sense? Maybe not.

Anyway – the writing is surprisingly light-hearted and comedic than the first game or horror games in general. One particular character is basically writtten like a devilish, sarcastic Stephen King antagonist. That may or may not be to your liking. Humour tends to spook away the horror. 

All in all, I appreciate how they went a different way with Black Plague, and in its way this is an extremely worthwhile game in a world where sequels tend to tread same ground.

REQUIEM, though... so, you know how sometimes there's like a "10 new levels!" or a "time trials expansion" pack to a story-driven, self-contained game?

Yeah, Requiem is one of those and it's sort of a snore. Basically, it's Penumbra: Aperture Science – nine boring "hit the lever" puzzle stages with a fourth-wall breaking female computer voice cracking jokes on someone's behalf. Art assets seem to be recycled from the earlier Penumbra games and their scrapped content, and the ending doesn't really relate to the main game story. It's basically a crock.

7699959.review:
Penumbra – Black Plague est le second épisode de la trilogie Penumbra. On le commence sur les chapeaux de roues, directement à partir du cliffhanger du premier volet de la série, avec un Phillip à la santé mentale vacillante après les évènements de la mine.

Alerte aux spoilers !  D:

Lancé sur les traces de son père, Phillip s’aventure toujours plus profondément dans le sol Inuit du Groenland. Ayant franchi l’épreuve de l’exploitation minière, il se retrouve dans une installation scientifique, elle aussi en apparence désaffectée, ou plutôt vidée de sa population.

Ce nouvel environnement contraste énormément avec celui des souterrains du premier épisode, creusés à même le roc et soutenus difficilement par des poutres de bois pourris ou du béton en ruine. Les murs sont âcres, le carrelage au sol est décrépi, les lourdes portes en acier n’inspirent rien qui vaille si on venait à révéler ce qui se trouve derrière elles, les éclairages sont défaillants et des traces de sang ou de substance non identifiée sont parsemées dans les couloirs. Tout indique qu’il y a eu un désastre scientifique effroyable dont les fantômes arpentent encore les allées de l’implantation. 

Cette coupure de design est frappante et intensifie énormément ce côté mystérieux de l’intrigue. Le fait de trouver cet « abri » scientifique au cœur des entrailles de la terre est un sacré coup de génie, pouvant certes paraître classique, mais reste terriblement efficace. Phillip trouve des réponses à des questions, mais bien d’autres nouvelles interrogations trottent dans la tête de Phillip et du joueur. 

Qui dit nouvel environnement dit nouvelles créatures, et non des moindres, car plus intelligentes et plus aux aguets, certaines demanderont au joueur d’avoir recours à plus de tactique pour les neutraliser. 

Penumbra – Black Plague est bien plus oppressant que son aîné, dans le sens où Phillip se retrouvera plus souvent confronté aux monstres dans des couloirs sans issues et que ces derniers nous recherchent tant que l’on respire encore. L’amélioration du gameplay se trouve notamment dans le fait que l’on est à poil face au danger, plus de pioche miracle pour se tirer de là.

L’accent de cet épisode est mis sur la santé mentale de Phillip, qui est directement liée à la rencontre avec une certaine entité. De cette rencontre n’en sortira pas que du bien, et permettra de sacrés rebondissements.

Les énigmes sont toujours savamment construites, la bande son est maitrisée, les graphismes et les effets de lumières toujours aussi propres, sans plus, et l’ambiance est toujours à se cryogéniser le sang. 

Tous ces éléments contribuent à faire l’alchimie effrayante du jeu, diaboliquement grisante au point de parcourir les couloirs avec un plaisir masochiste ! On se méprendrait même à jouer à Dead Space, ou à Doom 3, la gravité en moins.

Le dénouement de l’histoire est sympathique, peut-être un peu too much, mais reste très acceptable.

Au final, Penumbra – Black Plague marque un grand coup dans le domaine vidéoludique de l’horreur, montrant qu’avec peu de moyens, on peut faire de grandes choses !


PS : Pour Penumbra – Requiem, le dernier épisode de la trilogie, je ne le recommande pas car ce n’est qu’un Portal-like sans saveurs, dont le seul ennemi est l’ennui. Même si il est devenu un jeu d’adresse et de réflexion démontrant encore que les développeurs en ont dans la cervelle, quelle déception ! On y joue juste pour la fin, qui est certes troublante, mais vraiment accessoire au final, on aurait juré que l’histoire ne tenait que pour deux épisodes ... Dommage

5389085.review:
Another excellent game from Frictional. Or TWO games, rather! Penumbra: Black Plague AND Penumbra: Requiem.

   One word of warning about Requiem, though: it's pure, 100% puzzle-solving. Well, okay, a couple of treacherous bits of jumping and/or timing here and there; but apart from environmental hazards, there's no way of dying. Which makes it less of an action/horror game than the others, and yet oddly spooky and suspenseful in spite of all that.  

   I still spent a good deal of the game half-expecting something nasty to jump out at me, but alas..! I would in any case heartily recommend this pack to everyone who enjoyed the first Penumbra, but would suggest that only those who enjoy the puzzle-solving antics in and of themselves proceed to Requiem. Rest assured that Black Plague will safely see to all your pants-soiling needs, in any case.

   (Oh, and don't attempt to play Requiem if tired and grumpy, 'cause there's head-fucking aplenty. Personally I waited 'til I was in a particularly "intelligent" mood - which doesn't happen often, let me tell you - before committing myself to a session. Though I will be the first to confess, I'm pretty dismal at these puzzle-solving games! Stare me in the face all you like, chances are I STILL won't see you...)

Verdict: 9/10.

896718.review: The roots of Amnesia are undeniable in this standout entry from Frictional's sci-fi series. If the first part was a cautious walk the second is a full-tilt run: tighter narrative, better graphics, excellent level design, evocative sound, great enemies and even better physics puzzles. It also has the distinction of being a game that effectively crosses genres from mystery to horror fantasy to existential sci-fi and even buddy comedy on whim (granted the "buddy" is a psychic tumor). Admittedly Penumbra isn't an entirely frightening experience for the fact that the antagonists are a vulnerable batch of evil aliens (similar to Metro's Dark Ones). It absolutely has it's moments though, particularly the unseen creatures taking residence in the Kennel's long, dark hallwalls and the moment you're locked in with a person that's just succumb to infection. Bringing up the inventory or reading notes in real time also adds a tremendous ammount of immediacy to the proceedings (try fumbling through your pockets to heal while enemies are searching for you and you'll see). There is a third episode but it's a forgettable platformer which adds nothing to the narrative, nor the impressive ending, of Penumbra. Black Plague takes the sterility inherent  to puzzle games and injects the kind of story and mood you'd never really expect it could have.

3728103.review:
Where Overture was a chilling but deeply flawed attempt at survival horror, Penumbra Black Plague is a much more tightly focused experience that draws on its themes to spin a genuinely thought-provoking and compelling narrative.

Storytelling has always been a key part of the experience with Frictional Games. Even during their more uneven outings, one could still respect their vision when it came to exploring dark and disturbing subject matter. While I still view SOMA as being the pinnacle of Frictional’s storytelling prowess, there’s little doubt in my mind that Black Plague is a close second in that regard. Black Plague explores the nature of the human psyche and how we perceive our surroundings - there will often be moments here where you will be left wondering just how much of what you’re seeing is real, and what is an illusion. This is taken to heart-wrenching extremes during the story’s final act.

The climax builds to a perplexing quandary: rather than ending on a scare-fest, it instead forces you the question the morality of your actions and whether your perception on the events you’ve seen has been skewed by your own limited understanding - a true Lovecraftian story then. Black Plague may have its share of monster chases and unsettling imagery, but what really propels the horror in this story is the grander implications of how your mind sees the world around you. It never stops tripping you up and finding new ways to surprise you. Sadly, the actual ending leaves something to be desired - rather than building up to any grand revelation or twist, the story merely splutters to halt and ends on an unclear note. I suspect this may have been some sort of resource limitation for Frictional at the time, but it does places a bit of black mark against what is otherwise a sublime story.

The rest of the game is more or less what you’d expect from Frictional Games - the first-person interface is unique and intuitive; the puzzle solving flows naturally; and the removal of combat in this installment means that you are no longer able to overcome to physical threats that you’ll face, making for a tenser set of encounters. The environments here place more of an emphasis on the industrial as you delve further into the research station, surrounded by archaic computer technology and hard-edged utilitarian surfaces. Although the Penumbra games are starting to show their age, the effective use of low-key lighting and sound ensure that they’ve lost none of their creepiness over the years.

For those enamoured with Frictional’s later works, Penumbra is still an adventure worth delving into, with Black Plague easily the strongest of the two main entries. It may be rough around the edges and lack a strong conclusion, but the dark intriguing story and haunting atmosphere will keep you gripped from beginning to end.

1547253.review:
Penumbra is a horror/adventure series by Frictional Games, the developers of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. While not nearly as good as that horror masterpiece, there is still a lot to enjoy in Penumbra. In fact, it's very easy to see how Amnesia eventually came to be what it is - its elements are on full display here, albeit in early forms. While the games do have some scary bits, overall the fright-factor is not quite where it could be. This is mainly due to the somewhat dated graphics and easily thwarted enemies (which, unlike in Amnesia, can usually be killed). The puzzles are generally pretty decent, with only a few solutions being particularly obtuse. So, while not perfect, the series is still worth a look for horror/adventure game fans, especially those who enjoyed Amnesia and are interested in seeing the roots of that game and supporting its developers.

Penumbra: Black Plague is the 2nd game in the series. It improves upon many aspects of Overture, and is the best of the 3 games.

1883660.review:
Black Plague, sequel to Overture, is yet again an astoundingly good game. Several of the wonky game-mechanics of it's predecessor, chiefly unweildy melee combat, have been scrubbed.

The story, progressing ever onward, is well written from beginning to end. For a game like this, with low production values and a small dev. team, to weave such an interesting story is quite the accomplishment. It even has an ending which noticeably stirs the subtle messages earlier in the game.

A genuinely eerie game, though incredibly satisfying to progress in, figure out, and ultimately beat, Black Plague is a great game, through and through, and should definitely be tried out at the very least.

Unless you don't have what it takes? Can you play Penumbra end to end without fiddling with your gamma? Muting your sound? Reading through walk-throughs? I highly suggest avoiding the aforementioned. To do so would be to defeat the purpose of the game, and really take from the enjoyment of it all.

2085726.review:
Like the first part, Overture, Frictional Games again manages to capture the true essence of survival horror improving from last time by incorporating better sounds, atmosphere and a somewhat tighter story with memorable characters. The voice acting was superb throughout but while the humourous moments helped lighten the mood faster in order to regain that "SHOCK" moment more often, I felt that this rushed approach wasn't well executed nor received.
The total removement of the combat system is what I think makes this game far superior than its predesseccor. You have to run and hide rather than club your enemies to death.
The best thing about Black Plague was by far its script, it never fails to keep the player both captivated and horrified. The end message was well thought out and delievered although the overall shortness of the campaign may disappoint the die-hard fans who were looking for something a bit longer.
Overall, this game is superb and fully deserves your time and money.

1568722.review: Like Amnesia, Penumbra Black Plague is the type of horror game where you experience pure fear in the presence of enemies, because unlike more traditional horror games like Doom or Slient Hill you don't have a shotgun or any means of defense other than running, hiding and hoping to god you're wearing clean underwear. 2252926.review:
The Penumbra series is one of the only horror series left in modern gaming - story driven, challenging, dark, and believe it or not, scary.  People call Doom, F.E.A.R., Dead Space, and Resident Evil 4-5 horror games even though they're no more than just shooters.  If you're looking for something more authentic and deep, then give Penumbra a try.  Remember to play them at night.

This game shines brightly in both survival horror and existential horror.  Dialogue is one of its strongest aspects, and Penumbra is uniquely good at developing characters quickly, off screen even, and building up toward an inevitable encounter.  Overture does this numerous times as does Black Plague.

Overture is a slow burning torch while Black Plague is a rollercoaster through hell.  Both are only about 4 hours long.  They are not mere jumpscare fests, having very few if any.  But the uneasiness and terror are constant.  Overture is the only game from Frictional Games to feature combat, so Black Plague has none.  

They are also known for their practical, sometimes physics based "puzzles" but they are not really puzzles, just problems.  Requiem however, the unnecessary expansion for Black Plague, has puzzles.  Requiem is purely a puzzle game; cleverly designed puzzles that are challenging by the genre's standards.  But Requiem is an unnecessary story expansion designed to deliver a more clarified ending because small minded gamers find Black Plague's brilliant ambiguity too much.

Penumbra is a must play.  It has aged exceptionally well, being wonderfully fluid save for turning valves/wheels.  It is better than Amnesia, mostly due to it being far better written.

A first-person horror game with a focus on exploration and puzzle solving, "Penumbra: Black Plague" is a fantastic departure from your traditional survival horror game. Unlike other games in "survival horror" canon, in which you can rely on weaponry to cut a swath through your enemies, "Black Plague" forces the player to rely on stealth or running away to avoid your enemies.

My one gripe with the game is how short it is: I managed to beat it in about 5 hours. Nevertheless, a fantastic game. Genuinely creepy, and with a rather neat story. Try it out!

5105990.review:
Perhaps the most frightening game I have ever played.  Though there is nothing particularly original in the design, it is executed extremely well. The game maintains a constant feeling of helplessness and extreme paranoia interspersed with moments of well-executed levity.

The engine is rough around the edges (though it is less apparent here than in Penumra's previous episode, in which the combat was poorly executed), I highly recommend this game for anyone who wants to cower in a corner saying, "Oh god! Oh god! Oh god!" and then have a sleepless night.

In fact, I'm writing this review because I can't play the game anymore because it's 9 pm and I know if I play a second longer I won't get a wink (of sleep or otherwise).

You may want to play Penumbra: Overture before playing this game, as the plot continues from where the previous episode left off, but it is not necessary: the game can stand on its own.  And Penumbra: Overture isn't nearly as well-made.

Penumbra: Overture's story and style were wonderful, but being able to just beat most of the monsters to death greatly undermined the horror element. The developer listened to complaints, however (which is something I wish the bigger companies would do) and produced Black Plague, which single-handedly fixes all the major problems with the original while continuing the intriguing story that I loved so much before. No longer can you expect to fight your way out of a tight spot, so your only options are stealth and pegging it. As a result, the atmosphere can get RIDICULOUSLY intense and your opportunities to relax become increasingly few later on.

It's not quite the masterpiece of bone-shaking terror that Amnesia would become, but it's still bloody petrifying and easily worth looking into, particularly if you've already suffered through Amnesia and fancy even more abuse.

132876.review: The second installment of the Penumbra series that picks up immediately after the end of Penumbra Overture.  Right off the bat, the mere menu screen with it's dark, grimey visuals and it's deteriorated, darker music fills you with the dread of the horrors that await you, making you realize that everything is getting worse and more hopeless for our main protagonist.  Not much has changed gameplay-wise, keeping the scares high as ever, except now, that terrible combat system in Overture has been completely removed.  You will also find yourself meeting a new support character and an unexpected antagonist that evolves psychologically in the player's mind that not enough games have been able to pull off with their bad guys.  To be perfectly honest, I enjoyed this game more than Amnesia and I hope anyone who has played Amnesia will feel like this one will stack up nicely to it.

Before Amnesia there was Penumbra.

Even though it was Frictional's first foray into game development, the team showed their almost perfect understanding of what makes a game frightening. Just like its younger brother Amnesia, Penumbra succeeds at making you afraid of the dark all over again with creepy atmosphere and that feeling of dread that hangs over you as you desperately fumble your way through darkness.

If you enjoy survival horror -- and if you enjoyed Amnesia -- then turn out all the lights and prepare yourself for Penumbra.

Don't forget to lock your door...

1092960.review:
Imagine Half Life without firearms or even your crowbar. Black Plague features a significantly different art design over it's predecessor Overture. Featuring less abandoned mines and spider infested caves with underground facilities with advanced technology and a mutant plague virus that threatens the world. Sound familiar?

Black Plague however distinguishes itself in numerous ways to Overture. For one it's significantly more character driven. The original only had two major characters, the player and the enigmatic Red who wasnt even modeled ingame. Here you have a skitzophrenic voice in your head and zombies walking linoleum hallways.

Really what can be said about Black Plague? It suffers from the same problems as Overture, and vis-à-vis it features all the improvements so dearly needed for the game. So really... it's just a sequel that feels like it needs to be packaged with Overture instead of seperated.

La edición Gold de esta serie te ofrece el segundo capítulo (Black Plague) y el tercero (Requiem), por lo que recomiendo que juegues primero al Penumbra Overture (primer capítulo) para que te pongas en situación.
Penumbra Overture se centra más en los comienzos de la historia e invita a una exploración más pausada mientras vas resolviendo puzzles. En Black Plague encontrarás "más de lo mismo", pero con una mayor dosis de terror y puzzles dentro de unas instalaciones que recuerdan a Black Mesa (Half-Life) y en Penumbra Requiem te toparás con los puzzles puros y duros a través de diversos niveles que hacen pensar en el juego Portal. 8/10

87416.review:
Best played alone. In the dark. 

The dark atmosphere is a breeding ground for fear, and the interactive environment makes you feel like you're really there (honestly, having to open doors by pushing them open with your mouse might be one of the creepist game mechanics ever). The real trick to making it through is keeping your head: it's hard to solve mind numbing puzzles in a panic, and if there's one thing Penumbra can do, it's put you in a panic.

But don't get me wrong. Running and hiding is usually a very, very good idea.

If you like this, I also recommend Frictional's two other games: Penumbra Overture (the prequel) and Amnesia: The Dark Descent.

39592468.review:
"Terror" and "Horror" are adjectives that get applied to any game with a poorly lit hallway, and something that's trying to hurt your character.  That seems to be the most Frictional's games are capable of offering.

There are some notable improvements in development from the first Penumbra title, but they are few, and of little consequence to the overall quality of the game; it appears there's a very slow learning curve at Frictional, or they just don't care that much about the quality of their product.  Graphics are marginally better, but still haven't aged well over the last eight years.  Puzzles continue to be obtuse and too frequent.  Gameplay remains crude with clumsy control over drawers, doors, and other objects.  The toil of plodding through these games might be tolerable if there was a worthwhile narrative, but I didn't feel it was there.

I only found the time and interest to finish this title while recovering from the flu.  The game does not scare, doesn't entertain, but it does help pass the time and dull the senses while waiting for Nyquil to kick in.
